[Caraviello]: Thank you very much.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: The library plays so many roles in the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: And this will be an integral part of our community.

[Caraviello]: So we went to the city and to the state to get public funding committed and we also committed to secure significant support from the private sector.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: There we go.

[Caraviello]: I never once thought of this as a job.

[Caraviello]: It was something that I wanted to do.

[Caraviello]: As I said, when Terry Carter interviewed me for an interview, he says, how did you get involved?

[Caraviello]: And I said, you know, I said, I was like kind of a young kid, 45 years old, and I was kind of at the crossroads, you know, with young kids, and a friend invited me to a Kiwanis meeting.

[Caraviello]: And

[Caraviello]: I got to sit with Paul, and back then there was like 80, 90 people, but they were all pillars of the community.

[Caraviello]: And I'd sit there and I'd listen to their stories, and I said, geez, I'd like to be that person one day.

[Caraviello]: And Paul mentored me along, and here I am today.

[Caraviello]: So I thank the Kiwanis for really getting me involved with the community and showing me what community involvement was all about, because I didn't come from, you know, it's not something that I did, or my dad didn't do it either, so.

[Caraviello]: And I didn't do it by myself.

[Caraviello]: And we got the ball rolling on that.

[Caraviello]: So those are two real things I've did that I'm real proud of.

[Caraviello]: Who in the world would ever know where to find an elevator for free?

[Caraviello]: Really, we got a call and the lady said, I need an elevator for my house, I'm saying.

[Caraviello]: I made a couple of calls in like, in three hours I had an elevator.

[Caraviello]: And I called him back and he says, remember Christmas?

[Caraviello]: He says, we're gonna have an elevator for you.

[Caraviello]: And we got people to put it in for free.

[Caraviello]: And this was from a guy who hadn't been out of this house in four years.

[Caraviello]: We also, we did a home of a veteran, what apparently his daughter.

[Caraviello]: And we got together with the community and volunteers and did almost $300,000 worth of work in this house free.

[Caraviello]: So when I say I started, we did the food program, but it's just things I've done over the years.

[Caraviello]: I don't know how they came to the past, but they did.

[Caraviello]: But it's the integrity of the office that's the question here.

[Caraviello]: And this isn't a question just for MEDFED.

[Caraviello]: This is why throughout the whole country

[Caraviello]: We're seeing people losing faith in elections by exactly what happened in our city.

[Caraviello]: It's not a Trump thing or a thing.

[Caraviello]: But again, I was a full supporter of bringing in an election coordinator because I thought we would do a better job.

[Caraviello]: And the job has gotten worse.

[Caraviello]: If I had to do that vote over again, I would have probably left to keep it in the hands of the clerk.

[Caraviello]: Because when the clerk ran the elections in prior years,

[Caraviello]: We've never, ever had these kinds of issues.

[Caraviello]: People sitting here till 1 o'clock in the morning, waiting for ballots, waiting for questions.

[Caraviello]: You had tapes that didn't add up to the results that were posted.

[Caraviello]: Numerous, numerous errors, like Councilor Beall said, dating back to,

[Caraviello]: printing of the ballots, wrong instructions.

[Caraviello]: People get, I don't know how our computer system allowed us to print out three and four ballots per person, per household in different wards.

[Caraviello]: I came in here with a stack of eight ballots in one house.

[Caraviello]: How does that happen?

[Caraviello]: We have no idea how many of those ballots were sitting out there with no accountability.

[Caraviello]: How many ballots did we print?

[Caraviello]: How many ballots are left over now?

[Caraviello]: again, counting ballots that were supposed to be in public.

[Caraviello]: Those things just shouldn't happen.

[Caraviello]: And I say, and this is the reason people don't want to come out and vote, not just in here, but throughout the country, because of the integrity of what goes on here.

[Caraviello]: We've investigated people in this building, the lesser things, I think,

[Caraviello]: Some sort of outside audit needs to be done to find out why these mistakes occurred again and again, especially when Secretary of State's called you in the morning of that election telling you were doing things wrong.

[Caraviello]: And after they hung up on you, your people went back and said, don't listen to what they told you.

[Caraviello]: You do what I tell you to do.

[Caraviello]: That's not how this process is supposed to work.

[Caraviello]: So be fair and equal to everybody.

[Caraviello]: You shouldn't be telling people who to vote for in elections.

[Caraviello]: You shouldn't be telling people what

[Caraviello]: What kind of materials?

[Caraviello]: If somebody wants to bring something in their pocket with them, then they're allowed to do it, as long as it's not open to the public.

[Caraviello]: We had improper training of the officials here.

[Caraviello]: We were understaffed at the polls.

[Caraviello]: Every election, we always had someone checking in and out.

[Caraviello]: That's not the process anymore.

[Caraviello]: Again, I'm not disputing the results.

[Caraviello]: I'm not saying they would have changed.

[Caraviello]: You know, George and I come from a different generation.

[Caraviello]: It was pride in the city.

[Caraviello]: During my high school years, we used to go to the away games with like four buses of kids.

[Caraviello]: God couldn't get a ticket on some years.

[Caraviello]: The lines used to be around the corner.

[Caraviello]: People waiting for tickets.

[Caraviello]: Thanksgiving Day used to sell out weeks before the game.

[Caraviello]: And that was not the pride of the community.

[Caraviello]: It was our football team, our sports teams.

[Caraviello]: We were there.

[Caraviello]: That's what kids went to the school for.

[Caraviello]: And that's part of the reason our teams have faltered over the years.

[Caraviello]: And that's why you're seeing a lot of kids going to different schools now, because we have to get that pride back.

[Caraviello]: It was there when I was there.

[Caraviello]: It was there when George was there, when we were dominating teams.

[Caraviello]: And you wanted to go to the games.

[Caraviello]: You went to the hockey games.

[Caraviello]: You went to the base.

[Caraviello]: You went to games.

[Caraviello]: Yeah, you don't forget the 90s with that soccer program.

[Caraviello]: Yeah, there was some guy that was on the team, I don't forget his name.

[Caraviello]: I guess it's not coming in more often.

[Caraviello]: Chris, there should be something recognizing our Super Bowl team there at Hormel.

[Caraviello]: Yeah, there should be.

[Caraviello]: Something to recognize in the team.

[Caraviello]: Yeah.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: I think we all know Henry and Evelyn for their work in Medford, which is tireless, but I've known Henry a long time.

[Caraviello]: For those who don't know him, Henry is well-renowned throughout the state of Massachusetts for his work in that community.

[Caraviello]: And he doesn't get the recognition sometimes that he deserves, but those of us in the hometown, we all know and we recognize his commitment to people with disabilities and things like that.

[Caraviello]: So I just want to salute Henry for his work and glad he's getting some recognition, both him and Evelyn for all the things they do.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Caraviello]: I appreciate Councilor Bears's putting this on there.

[Caraviello]: This isn't just Willis Ave.

[Caraviello]: We're gridlocked in the city.

[Caraviello]: at certain times of the day.

[Caraviello]: I know some of the improvements we made for safety is we've cut down the size of the roads, we've cut down turns.

[Caraviello]: So now people are sitting in traffic for crazy periods of time, they're getting frustrated, and they're going down all these side roads.

[Caraviello]: They say, this is just Willis-Eve.

[Caraviello]: In the morning, the traffic is backing up into Winchester on Winter Street.

[Caraviello]: It's backing up past the train station.

[Caraviello]: This morning,

[Caraviello]: Took me 38 minutes to get into the square from my house in West Medford.

[Caraviello]: High Street is backed up everywhere.

[Caraviello]: So it's a problem, especially between the morning hours and the afternoon hours.

[Caraviello]: We're just gridlocked, no matter where you go in the city.

[Caraviello]: And frustration is, people are going down all these side roads.

[Caraviello]: If you use Waze, it's taking you everywhere.

[Caraviello]: I mean, we've been shut down every road in the city for, you know, certain hours of the day.

[Caraviello]: It's just, it's getting unbearable.

[Caraviello]: It's everywhere.

[Caraviello]: I'm hearing from all the neighbors and everywhere saying, I can't take the traffic.

[Caraviello]: People are flying down my streets.

[Caraviello]: examined the whole city, not just Willis Avenue.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Caraviello]: This goes handed in with what Councilor Bears just talked about.

[Caraviello]: Fulton Street,

[Caraviello]: I know, as Councilor Scarpelli said, people are just living with it now, but it's backing up further and further up the hill, and no one's really listening, watching those signs saying, you know, resident only.

[Caraviello]: They're pretty much going down all those neighborhood streets and flooding those neighborhoods as the traffic keeps getting further up.

[Caraviello]: If you live in the West Method area, you're seeing the lights at Route 16 and Winter Street, three or four cars get through.

[Caraviello]: And the problem over there is because there's two sets of lights on Route 16 that go off in the morning when there's really no one over there, causing the traffic to back up.

[Caraviello]: So now you get three cars go through.

[Caraviello]: traffic's backing up everywhere, and it's backing up on the Boston Ave now on some mornings.

[Caraviello]: So along with the motion we just passed, this is something that has to be looked into.

[Caraviello]: Again, this is not so much a city problem, but it's a DCR problem, and we're still waiting for the lights on South Street to get going.

[Caraviello]: What do we have there?

[Caraviello]: We still got the same blinking light.

[Caraviello]: So now the people are going down South Street.

[Caraviello]: And before, they used to get on Mystic Avenue, but now if you notice, they blocked off the other turn there.

[Caraviello]: So now we're gonna be flooding Mystic Avenue with more cars, because if you come down over that way, your only access to 93 is to go all the way into Somerville now.

[Caraviello]: and just making our traffic problems larger and larger without thinking before we make decisions.

[Caraviello]: It's getting worse by the day.

[Caraviello]: I mean, people, the kids are late going to school in the morning.

[Caraviello]: The bus can't make it there.

[Caraviello]: And they're getting their three, they get three tidies and you got a problem at school.

[Caraviello]: First of all, thank you, and it's my honor and privilege to be here this evening.

[Caraviello]: Excellent, excellent.

[Caraviello]: Well, I live right down the street, as many of you know.

[Caraviello]: And I went to school with everybody in the whole city.

[Caraviello]: If you look on the wall here, you see many pictures of people who made the center what it is, and I remember many of them growing up, but there's one in particular.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: 13 years ago, when I decided to run for office, as you said, I had always been involved in the community, doing different things, but I was out campaigning, out walking the streets, and I came upon Wally Counts' house.

[Caraviello]: I didn't know that it was his house,

[Caraviello]: I rang the bell, it was a hot summer night.

[Caraviello]: Oh Rick, how you doing?

[Caraviello]: It's hot, come in and have some water.

[Caraviello]: So we sat down in his living room with his wife and we had a talk and he said, you know Rick, I've known you a long time, you've always done good for the community.

[Caraviello]: And he says, I've supported a lot of candidates that I thought were going to be good candidates and do good for the community down here.

[Caraviello]: He says they didn't live up to their promise.

[Caraviello]: After an hour of talking and I made a commitment to him that I would always make sure that I'd be down here and take care of this community as long as I was able to.

[Caraviello]: And I hope Mr. Counts is proud of what he supported 13 years ago.

[Caraviello]: Well, you have my wife there.

[Caraviello]: We've been married 47 years.

[Caraviello]: And we were both, we got married young.

[Caraviello]: And I was, you know, young, and my wife,

[Caraviello]: kind of brought me up, and so I hope that she's proud of the prison that she's developed.

[Caraviello]: My parents gave her a 22 when she was a little boy, and this is what I've grown up to be, and I owe it all to her.

[Caraviello]: I didn't really have any early role models or heroes.

[Caraviello]: I'm an only child.

[Caraviello]: My mother passed away a few weeks after I was born.

[Caraviello]: I don't have like brothers or sisters like other people did.

[Caraviello]: So being in the NHL is a little different.

[Caraviello]: So I didn't really have anyone to look up to.

[Caraviello]: Just my parents, and that was about it.

[Caraviello]: Believe it or not, we still hang with our core group of junior high school friends that moved on to high school, and we go out probably every couple of weeks with our core 10 or 12 people.

[Caraviello]: And Peter Petrella.

[Caraviello]: I know Petrella.

[Caraviello]: Peter Petrella.

[Caraviello]: That was the other Peter.

[Caraviello]: There was two Peters.

[Caraviello]: It was two Peters, that's Peter the Accountant.

[Caraviello]: This is his cousin.

[Caraviello]: Tony Daddario, George Garofalo, Jack Santoro.

[Caraviello]: We started out the Lincoln Junior High and we remained friends forever.

[Caraviello]: And then over the years we took in some of the West Bedford kids, The Clocks, Kenny Mayarco.

[Caraviello]: And I say, and to this day, we're friends.

[Caraviello]: I can tell you now, I'm certainly not the same person I was 12 years ago.

[Caraviello]: I've grown, I've learned, and I've changed my attitude on a lot of things.

[Caraviello]: It's helped me to grow and grow into a different person.

[Caraviello]: Though I always had a value system, the value system has changed over the years.

[Caraviello]: And again, I always managed to stay involved in the community as I am now.

[Caraviello]: I still belong to the Kiwanis.

[Caraviello]: I still work at the food bank.

[Caraviello]: I do work at the library.

[Caraviello]: So as you know, I've been dedicated to this community my whole life.

[Caraviello]: And I don't come from, my parents never did this.

[Caraviello]: Where it came from is when I was like about 45, and I met a friend of mine.

[Caraviello]: He says, why don't you join a meeting at the corners for us?

[Caraviello]: I gave his number.

[Caraviello]: And it was kind of them who shaped me, because we met every week, and it was a bunch of community members.

[Caraviello]: And I would listen to them, and they would tell the stories of the good things they did.

[Caraviello]: There was a few political people in there, but they were the ones that actually taught me community service.

[Caraviello]: And I kind of commend them for doing it.

[Caraviello]: Back then, there was a lot of political people, and there were business and community leaders.

[Caraviello]: I learned from them, and I aspired to be them.

[Caraviello]: I was the young kid back then, and they were all older.

[Caraviello]: But you listen to the stories they would tell, even the politician stories.

[Caraviello]: They talked about the good things they did.

[Caraviello]: As I tell even my new Councilors, there isn't a better feeling than doing something good for somebody who really needs it.

[Caraviello]: And I'm not talking about, you know, like Joe Jones calling, hey, can you fix the pothole?

[Caraviello]: But somebody who really needs help that doesn't relate to your job as a city.

[Caraviello]: And it's a real good feeling when you do something good for somebody.

[Caraviello]: Remember the Happy Haddock?

[Caraviello]: We used to meet there.

[Caraviello]: And when the Happy Haddock closed, we didn't have a place to go.

[Caraviello]: And the club almost broke up because over the food.

[Caraviello]: Yeah.

[Caraviello]: We were going to eat and finally we ended up going to Bocelli's.

[Caraviello]: Bocelli's, absolutely.

[Caraviello]: Yeah, we were going to different places and the food was

[Caraviello]: was the most important thing and also got the club almost disbanded because we had nowhere to go.

[Caraviello]: With food.

[Caraviello]: And I say, you know, I think everybody in the room, you know, it's a family thing.

[Caraviello]: We all grew up with food.

[Caraviello]: Food was, you sat around on a Sunday and you had dinner with your family.

[Caraviello]: I know now that's a forgotten thing, but

[Caraviello]: I think most of the people in this room, remember you went to your grandparents' house on a Sunday for dinner, or they came to yours, and even as a family, you sat down every night and you had dinner together.

[Caraviello]: And again, people, everyone does take out, even my own kids I see.

[Caraviello]: you know, home-cooked meals.

[Caraviello]: My wife still cooks a meal every night for us and our hosts, and she keeps the tradition going.

[Caraviello]: Trying to get our kids there is a whole nother thing, though.

[Caraviello]: It's taught me to respect everybody in this community and to be available to everybody.

[Caraviello]: I think everybody knows part of the thing is Rick always answers the phone when people call.

[Caraviello]: I'm always available for everybody.

[Caraviello]: If you need something, I'll come to your house.

[Caraviello]: I don't need you to come to me.

[Caraviello]: And also, I don't like emailing people.

[Caraviello]: I don't like texting.

[Caraviello]: If you want something, I'd rather talk to you in person.

[Caraviello]: Everybody knows if you need something, I'll be at your house.

[Caraviello]: Anything you ever needed, I'm here.

[Caraviello]: And that's me.

[Caraviello]: I'm more of a hands-on type person.

[Caraviello]: Well, as we said earlier, you know, I was always involved with the community and do other things.

[Caraviello]: I did want to do it at an earlier time.

[Caraviello]: I remember, I don't know if you remember, remember when they were doing all the gas work over here?

[Caraviello]: They were tearing up all the streets, putting the gas line in.

[Caraviello]: I was kind of, I kind of got involved with that and I was kind of angry because the gas company just wasn't taking care of the people.

[Caraviello]: And I was, I had thought about running back then, but

[Caraviello]: You shouldn't run when you're angry or have a cause.

[Caraviello]: You should run because you want to run to do the right thing and not have a cause.

[Caraviello]: And my kids had all been grown, so I had the time to dedicate to it.

[Caraviello]: And I felt it was a good move up for me.

[Caraviello]: And again, my friends at the Kiwanis, they inspired me to do it because I saw them, I saw many of them there.

[Caraviello]: Like I said, we were local leaders at the time.

[Caraviello]: And I think that was just an inspiration for me.

[Caraviello]: One of the things I don't like right now

[Caraviello]: is we've become a community of old Medford and new Medford.

[Caraviello]: And we have a divide in the community, and I don't like the divide.

[Caraviello]: I didn't grow up in a community that was divided.

[Caraviello]: I grew up in one community.

[Caraviello]: And that's one of my goals is to bring everybody back to the middle so we're all together as a community.

[Caraviello]: Even if you just moved here in the last couple of years, people like us who lived here our whole lives, I think we need to be one community.

[Caraviello]: That's one of my biggest things that I'd like to do if I was elected mayor was get the unity back.

[Caraviello]: I want the community that we grew up in where everybody was friendly with everybody.

[Caraviello]: No more us versus them.

[Caraviello]: So it really wasn't in my thoughts up until last year.

[Caraviello]: And after the last election,

[Caraviello]: My vote total was quite high, higher than it had ever been.

[Caraviello]: And some new people came onto the council, and I had to take the back seat.

[Caraviello]: I'd always been a leader in the council, and now I was on the minority end.

[Caraviello]: Welcome to my life, okay?

[Caraviello]: I was on the minority end.

[Caraviello]: I didn't like sitting there doing nothing every week.

[Caraviello]: I mean, I voted correctly and everything, but there were some issues that I would have liked to have done, but as they say, if you don't have the votes, you don't have the votes.

[Caraviello]: So that kind of spurned my decision, and we had a little family meeting at the house, and it didn't go over too well.

[Caraviello]: with some members of the family, but I moved on and here I am today.

[Caraviello]: It's been a tough time.

[Caraviello]: I think my wife will tell you how hard it's been on her.

[Caraviello]: It's been tough on me, I'm out every day, and it's really been pressing.

[Caraviello]: It's a lot harder than I ever thought it was gonna be.

[Caraviello]: I think she's I think she's on board now okay um and I get it it's hard for her mm-hmm I you know I can't keep dragging her everywhere you know she's got her things to do and she's a grandmother you know and yes and it's

[Caraviello]: Taking her away for some things that she likes to do with the kids and I said listen It's only another month away says we can I said you can't I says you gotta stop being a grandma for like the next five weeks Yeah, which is hard for her because you know, she wants to be the grandma absolutely So it's been a little long a little tough.

[Caraviello]: Okay on all of us.

[Caraviello]: I

[Caraviello]: She's my rock.

[Caraviello]: She's my inspiration.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: And again, she inspires me to do better.

[Caraviello]: She can't say that on TV.

[Caraviello]: Mm-hmm.

[Caraviello]: About my wife?

[Caraviello]: About being with her, you know.

[Caraviello]: Believe it or not.

[Caraviello]: I know her better than she knows her.

[Caraviello]: I know everything about her.

[Caraviello]: I know, I can tell as soon as I walk in the house with the face on the wall.

[Caraviello]: I said, you know, I write in, I sense the attitude.

[Caraviello]: I can read her to a T. Me, I'm a little more complex.

[Caraviello]: I tell her, I tell her, I says, you know, I says, we've been married 47 years and you still haven't figured me out yet.

[Caraviello]: I'm a little more complex than she is.

[Caraviello]: I know I can tell, as soon as I walk in the house, I know if this is a situation, if I've done something wrong.

[Caraviello]: No, she can't fool me.

[Caraviello]: I know her to a T. I know.

[Caraviello]: Probably the most proud of is the Medford Public Library.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: I worked four years to bring that to Medford, going to the conference every year.

[Caraviello]: And there'd be a library table there.

[Caraviello]: It was a convention for municipal governments.

[Caraviello]: I would go there and the library would be open.

[Caraviello]: I said, you know, that all these communities were getting libraries.

[Caraviello]: And he says, oh, he says, is Smith on the list?

[Caraviello]: No.

[Caraviello]: Oh, jeez.

[Caraviello]: So after three or four, after the fourth year,

[Caraviello]: I finally got us on the list.

[Caraviello]: And the library foundation came to MedFed, and they agreed that we needed a library.

[Caraviello]: And this is something, so I brought it to Mayor Burke, and Mayor Burke could have told me, Rick, you know, we're not doing it.

[Caraviello]: But she took it, and between the two of us, we got the $12 million in upfront financing to get the library.

[Caraviello]: I also sit on the Medford Public Library Foundation, I'm the co-chair, and we raised another $6 million to help defray the cost.

[Caraviello]: So in a sense, essentially,

[Caraviello]: City of Medford has a brand new state-of-the-art library for about 45 cents on the dollar, which in today's thing is a steal.

[Caraviello]: And that's probably one of the things I'm most proud of, that I could deliver something that to a community.

[Caraviello]: As a city councilor, not even as a mayor.

[Caraviello]: And I thank Mayor Burke for her help in doing that too.

[Caraviello]: Probably getting about 10,000 people a month that go through there.

[Caraviello]: We have a dedicated children's library now.

[Caraviello]: You actually have a room where you can have

[Caraviello]: someone like yourself speak, we bring authors in there.

[Caraviello]: Be surprised at the amount of people in this community that don't have access to the internet and don't have access to computers.

[Caraviello]: They go there, they do job interviews there.

[Caraviello]: You go there between 9 and 11, you can't get in the second floor because it's packed with children.

[Caraviello]: There's maker space, there's private study rooms.

[Caraviello]: It's a great building to be in.

[Caraviello]: That's probably my proudest achievement, that I can bring my own kids back there and say, this is what your father did.

[Caraviello]: So if I could give you a little story about the Bonsignori room.

[Caraviello]: Go for it.

[Caraviello]: We sold everything in the building.

[Caraviello]: Chairs, anything, anybody want anything?

[Caraviello]: We sold everything.

[Caraviello]: Name it, name it.

[Caraviello]: We named everything.

[Caraviello]: I knew Bob Bonsignori a little bit, and he reached out to me and said, geez, Ricky, I'd like to help out in the library, do something.

[Caraviello]: I said, great.

[Caraviello]: I says, I'll have the woman, the fundraiser, she'll give you a call, and whatever you want to do, you do.

[Caraviello]: So I gave him the number, and he calls me back and says, is this guy real?

[Caraviello]: I says, why?

[Caraviello]: He says, he's donating $400,000.

[Caraviello]: for the room, I said, whoa, Jesus.

[Caraviello]: I was like, taken back.

[Caraviello]: Because Bob doesn't live, he lives in California now.

[Caraviello]: But yeah, I was taken back when he came back with, he says, if I give you that much money, will you name it after, and he named it after his mother and father.

[Caraviello]: And he brought her there,

[Caraviello]: before the library opened as a surprise to show her that this is what I did for you as a son.

[Caraviello]: It was a touching moment.

[Caraviello]: He was one of my guys in high school, Bobby Bonsignore.

[Caraviello]: I was kind of shocked when he came up with that kind of number.

[Caraviello]: I thought maybe a couple thousand dollars, but when she said that number, I was like, whoa.

[Caraviello]: I have hope for our city.

[Caraviello]: And I want to bring it back

[Caraviello]: to a time when we're all united together.

[Caraviello]: And again, I think I said this before, I just don't like when I go, even when we have these meetings and people write on social media, you know,

[Caraviello]: People tell me, one of the knocks on me is, I'm Old Medford.

[Caraviello]: And I don't understand New Medford.

[Caraviello]: I am Old Medford, I was born and raised here.

[Caraviello]: A lot of my friends have since all moved away.

[Caraviello]: I chose to stay here.

[Caraviello]: I chose to raise my family here, and send my kids to school here.

[Caraviello]: I'm really proud of that fact.

[Caraviello]: And when people tell me that I'm Old Medford and I don't get it, they're wrong, I do get it.

[Caraviello]: I do get it, and I want,

[Caraviello]: The new people in Medford that moved here, I want them to get it too.

[Caraviello]: I want them to know the community that I grew up in and that you grew up in.

[Caraviello]: Many of these people in this room grew up in.

[Caraviello]: I want that community back again.

[Caraviello]: I want the closeness.

[Caraviello]: I want people to walk around the streets and be friendly.

[Caraviello]: I don't like when people walk by my house and neighbors and they don't even say hello anymore.

[Caraviello]: You don't know your neighbor anymore.

[Caraviello]: That's not...

[Caraviello]: That's not what I like.

[Caraviello]: You know me, I'm a friendly guy.

[Caraviello]: But I want that unity back in our community.

[Caraviello]: I want the community that I grew up in.

[Caraviello]: And I want everybody to be together.

[Caraviello]: Um, I don't know.

[Caraviello]: On a personal basis, or on a government basis?

[Caraviello]: I'm kind of a sensitive person, and I don't like when people talk bad about our community.

[Caraviello]: That doesn't sit well with me.

[Caraviello]: Like I said, I take pride in my community.

[Caraviello]: I love and I care, and I have concern for our community.

[Caraviello]: That's really what keeps me up at night.

[Caraviello]: And again, people know when you call, I want to be there.

[Caraviello]: I want to help people.

[Caraviello]: I've made my last probably 35 years of my life helping people.

[Caraviello]: And I want to continue doing that.

[Caraviello]: I've learned a lot, like I said, over the years.

[Caraviello]: I'm certainly not the same person I was 12 years ago.

[Caraviello]: I've grown on the job, I've learned.

[Caraviello]: I understand more now how government runs.

[Caraviello]: When you're the new guy, my first year, you had all these ideas.

[Caraviello]: I was going to change the world.

[Caraviello]: And you learn quickly, it's not happening.

[Caraviello]: It's not happening.

[Caraviello]: The ideas that you have don't come to fruition because I didn't understand how government worked.

[Caraviello]: And people try to equate the private world and the government world.

[Caraviello]: And I come from private business.

[Caraviello]: It doesn't work.

[Caraviello]: It's not the same mentality.

[Caraviello]: As a business owner, you make a decision today and it happens tomorrow.

[Caraviello]: You make a decision in government, well, we have to form a committee and do a study or bring in a consultant.

[Caraviello]: So that great idea you had now takes a year and a half to get done.

[Caraviello]: So that's kind of a frustration that happens.

[Caraviello]: I understand how government works and I understand what it takes to make government better also.

[Caraviello]: My dad had a small business and I worked with him.

[Caraviello]: It was mostly a woman-oriented business.

[Caraviello]: He taught me to make sure you don't treat people, treat everybody good.

[Caraviello]: Treat everybody the way you'd want to be treated.

[Caraviello]: My dad was a tough guy to work for.

[Caraviello]: I'm not gonna tell you he wasn't.

[Caraviello]: in his generation was work, then family.

[Caraviello]: Because if you didn't work, then, you know, so... You don't work, you don't eat.

[Caraviello]: The job came first and family came second.

[Caraviello]: That's how he grew up.

[Caraviello]: And I took some of that, but, you know, as I...

[Caraviello]: grew older, family came first, and job came second.

[Caraviello]: Dad couldn't understand that.

[Caraviello]: Because if I wanted to be home with the kids, he couldn't grasp that thought.

[Caraviello]: And that's, I think, where we kind of, after a while, I sort of went off into my own and doing something different.

[Caraviello]: Because Dad just, he was an old school working guy.

[Caraviello]: Works six days a week.

[Caraviello]: I remember my mother, all my other friends, their parents maybe came home at five.

[Caraviello]: My dad didn't come home till seven.

[Caraviello]: God bless my mother and my second mother.

[Caraviello]: she wouldn't eat until he came home.

[Caraviello]: And she had his dish there, and she had his glass with ice, and as the ice melted, she put more ice in, and as soon as he came in, he would drink Tab, remember Tab?

[Caraviello]: Yeah, I remember Tab.

[Caraviello]: So he'd drink Tab, and she wouldn't eat until he came home.

[Caraviello]: Yeah, yeah, that's what he drank.

[Caraviello]: Yeah, that was my dad, that's what they drank, Tab and Fresca.

[Caraviello]: I know my father was like that.

[Caraviello]: But what I did learn from him, even though all the people he had working there, but they all knew if they had a problem, they could go to him.

[Caraviello]: Whether it be a family problem or something, but he would always help out the family if they needed help.

[Caraviello]: And I think that's something I learned from him.

[Caraviello]: Family's very important to me.

[Caraviello]: It always has been.

[Caraviello]: Again, I was the only child.

[Caraviello]: I didn't have brothers and sisters, so my kids are very important to me.

[Caraviello]: My grandchildren are important to me.

[Caraviello]: We have eight.

[Caraviello]: Seriously?

[Caraviello]: Yeah.

[Caraviello]: They all have kids.

[Caraviello]: Yeah.

[Caraviello]: So Christmas time, don't come to my house at Christmas time because every kid has to get like a lot of stuff.

[Caraviello]: They get too many things.

[Caraviello]: Okay, okay.

[Caraviello]: And I tell my wife, you don't have to buy him that much stuff.

[Caraviello]: I said, they're getting old enough.

[Caraviello]: she won't like this, but my son's 45 and she'll call him up and ask him for his Christmas list.

[Caraviello]: Yeah, he says, stop.

[Caraviello]: What do you want for Christmas?

[Caraviello]: Give me a list for him.

[Caraviello]: And you know, if you grow up in an Italian family, the son is always at the top of the food chain.

[Caraviello]: Yeah, yeah.

[Caraviello]: But she'll call up at Christmas time, you know, I didn't get your list, what do you want for Christmas?

[Caraviello]: I said, stop, he's 45.

[Caraviello]: I'm a pretty, you know me, I laugh all the time.

[Caraviello]: We like to have fun.

[Caraviello]: It's good, no, it's good.

[Caraviello]: Some people tell me I don't take things seriously enough.

[Caraviello]: I do, but we can always have a little levity in anything we do.

[Caraviello]: I think I'm a leader.

[Caraviello]: I think I'm a very good leader.

[Caraviello]: I've led half a dozen organizations in the city.

[Caraviello]: And I've left every one of them in a better place than when I started.

[Caraviello]: I think I have courage.

[Caraviello]: I think I have a lot of courage.

[Caraviello]: I took a lot of courage to do what I'm doing now.

[Caraviello]: To stand up and do that.

[Caraviello]: When no one else in the city was standing up to do it, I stood up and said, I want to do this.

[Caraviello]: Okay, okay.

[Caraviello]: Integrity.

[Caraviello]: I value my integrity.

[Caraviello]: I value my reputation.

[Caraviello]: I've worked very hard to become a well-respected member of this community, and I intend to keep it.

[Caraviello]: And I say, as you know, I can go into any circle of this community, whether it be this community, the business community, the art community, I'm well-respected no matter where I go.

[Caraviello]: I'm very proud of my integrity in the community.

[Caraviello]: As you know, I'm here a lot.

[Caraviello]: I stop in just on the whim.

[Caraviello]: You know, I know a lot of people in the room.

[Caraviello]: I know a lot of people that are on that wall.

[Caraviello]: I really, you know, as you know, I don't really have any questions because I'm here all the time.

[Caraviello]: And if you've got questions, I ask you and I say, so, you know, you know me, I just, if I drive by, I stop in and say, hello, uh, you know, the, uh, people are having lunch, you know, we come in and we talk and, uh, I'm, you know, I'm glad to, you know, uh, be able to, uh, buy the people here lunches, uh, uh, you know, a few times a year.

[Caraviello]: I'm happy to do it because they're all, everyone here is a good, good people and I respect everybody in the room here.

[Caraviello]: I don't know.

[Caraviello]: I don't really have any.

[Caraviello]: I just want to.

[Caraviello]: I want to be a valued asset to our community.

[Caraviello]: I want to continue to do good things for the community.

[Caraviello]: It makes me feel good when I do good things.

[Caraviello]: Like I said, there isn't a better feeling

[Caraviello]: than when you actually help someone in real need.

[Caraviello]: And I'm not saying like political need, but someone who has a real problem that you could step in to help.

[Caraviello]: Like an example, there was a woman, family getting kicked out of their house.

[Caraviello]: And they were on a voucher and the rent went up.

[Caraviello]: And the young girl called me and says, they're kicking me out because I no longer meet the standard so I can stay in the house.

[Caraviello]: But I have the money to pay the extra thing, the extra rent.

[Caraviello]: And housing authority saying, well, you can't do that.

[Caraviello]: Even though you have the money, you have to go.

[Caraviello]: And the young girl didn't have a husband, but she had two kids.

[Caraviello]: And I went to the housing authority and says,

[Caraviello]: how can you kick this person out?

[Caraviello]: And there was a gentleman there who was fairly new.

[Caraviello]: He said, well, it's, you know, she has to, you know.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: All right, don't die on me now, come on, not under my interview.

[Caraviello]: I don't want to be blamed for this.

[Caraviello]: We've had a lot of

[Caraviello]: You all right?

[Caraviello]: Take a moment, relax.

[Caraviello]: Take your time.

[Caraviello]: You want to delete that part and start again?

[Caraviello]: But as I said, the gentleman that was helping her at the housing authority was a new guy, he didn't understand.

[Caraviello]: I said, she's saying I can pay the extra $100.

[Caraviello]: He said, I don't care if she can pay, she's gotta get out.

[Caraviello]: And I said, what do you mean she's gotta get out?

[Caraviello]: She's got nowhere to go.

[Caraviello]: I said, yo,

[Caraviello]: was supposed to be helping people, not hurting people.

[Caraviello]: Well, there's nothing I can do, and we went kind of long, and I reached out over his head, and we found there was a way to keep the woman in her house.

[Caraviello]: And she ended up staying, and she came up to me and hugged me and says, you know, you changed my life, and she thanked me for that.

[Caraviello]: And those are things that,

[Caraviello]: It wasn't something, it wasn't a council job.

[Caraviello]: It was something that you do and say, and those are the things that you want to do.

[Caraviello]: You want to help people.

[Caraviello]: Like I said, I'm not talking about fixing a pothole or something straight.

[Caraviello]: Helping someone that doesn't have anything to do with government, that doesn't have access maybe to, call me, can you help?

[Caraviello]: Senator Maki's office.

[Caraviello]: And you reach out to them because they don't know how to get in touch with Senator Maki or Representative Clark.

[Caraviello]: And that's how you really help people.

[Caraviello]: And get them to things that doesn't really have anything to do with your city job.

[Caraviello]: And I take pride in doing that thing.

[Caraviello]: And people know they can call me to get that stuff done.

[Caraviello]: Absolutely.

[Caraviello]: And this is a question I probably should have asked last week.

[Caraviello]: So I understand the process.

[Caraviello]: So this is for the Medford Square area, correct?

[Caraviello]: So we have needs on Mystic Avenue.

[Caraviello]: We have development needs throughout the whole city.

[Caraviello]: Why are we just doing Method Square?

[Caraviello]: I mean, are we going to look to diff every time a section of town needs work?

[Caraviello]: Are we going to look to put a diff in, let's say, in Wellington or Riverside Avenue or Mystic Avenue?

[Caraviello]: All they're doing is selling rock out of there.

[Caraviello]: I mean, they're operating a rock business out of that hole in the ground for the last four, five, six, seven years.

[Caraviello]: So I want a report from the building commission.

[Caraviello]: How long is that building permit gonna stay open for?

[Caraviello]: Well, they don't even have a building permit.

[Caraviello]: Well, they have some kind of permit.

[Caraviello]: Those people, they're operating a rock quarry business because all they're doing is selling rock out of there.

[Caraviello]: And that's not,

[Caraviello]: what it was supposed to be.

[Caraviello]: So if we can get some kind of report to the building commissioner, is that allowed for them to continue?

[Caraviello]: And how long is that?

[Caraviello]: Is their process going to stay open before there's actually going to be a house built there?

[Caraviello]: That's a normal idea.

[Caraviello]: The region built on ledge.

[Caraviello]: Yeah, my house is on ledge.

[Caraviello]: But Madam President, they're operating a rock white business over there.

[Caraviello]: Yeah.

[Caraviello]: That shouldn't be, is it allowed?

[Caraviello]: Are we getting any taxes for all the rock that they've sold out of there?

[Caraviello]: You need those rocks.

[Caraviello]: What we're seeing is community around us maximizing their zoning, allowing for the best use of their main corridors, while we in Medford

[Caraviello]: behind everyone else.

[Caraviello]: I don't know what the financial hit is.

[Caraviello]: Is there going to be this community next year going down the line?

[Caraviello]: Eventually these contracts will settle.

[Caraviello]: But see, and again, we have no idea where the lawsuits are going.

[Caraviello]: But you know, as you mentioned, you know, people leaving the city.

[Caraviello]: But what they do is they leave, and then we hire you part time to work here for like

[Caraviello]: So we're a full-time city with a bunch of part-time employees.

[Caraviello]: So our economic development director leaves.

[Caraviello]: He's working here 10 hours a month now.

[Caraviello]: We hired him for 10 hours.

[Caraviello]: The guy left.

[Caraviello]: The assessor left.

[Caraviello]: We have a part-time assessor here, and we borrow, and she works for Lowell.

[Caraviello]: So another part-time employee.

[Caraviello]: The person who just left the school, took a job in Cambridge.

[Caraviello]: They hired him to come back and do the budget, because they didn't have anybody to do the budget.

[Caraviello]: So all we do is, people walk out the door, we hire them back part-time.

[Caraviello]: We're a bunch of part-time employees here.

[Caraviello]: I mean, when does this stop?

[Caraviello]: When does this revolving door stop?

[Caraviello]: Everybody I look at, they're all life, most of them are lifetime members of this community.

[Caraviello]: We've never seen a revolving door like this ever.

[Caraviello]: I had a meeting before this, next door with somebody, and they asked me a legal question.

[Caraviello]: I was embarrassed to say, I says, I can't answer because I don't have a lawyer to call to give me a legal answer.

[Caraviello]: And I was embarrassed to tell that to five constituents in the other room when they asked me a question.

[Caraviello]: So how do you think that makes me feel as an elected official when I can't answer a constituent's question and I don't even know where to go to get the answer to their questions because we have no lawyer and we have no access to an attorney, which is really a shame.

[Caraviello]: But I would really like to know what the financial hit is going to be in this community when all these contracts settle and the guesstimate when all these lawsuits settle.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Thank you for the work.

[Caraviello]: And again, I think I see these guys working every day, and they don't miss a beat.

[Caraviello]: Quick question.

[Caraviello]: You mentioned a $465,000 settlement.

[Caraviello]: $475,000.

[Caraviello]: Was that a wage settlement for wages?

[Caraviello]: Yes, sir.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: And what union was that with?

[Caraviello]: That's my understanding.

[Caraviello]: That is the law, correct?

[Caraviello]: That's my understanding.

[Caraviello]: I thought everyone, over a certain amount of police, they're required to provide health insurance.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Caraviello]: I bet you most people in the city don't even know who Tom Aniletto is.

[Caraviello]: Tom was a silent giant in this community, especially for children that had disabilities.

[Caraviello]: Tom had two children that had disabilities, and he served this country as a veteran here, but he was a tireless volunteer in this community.

[Caraviello]: Most people don't know, but back in the 60s, Tom and another person started a program called the Friday Night Program, where they took children with disabilities into their home so the parents could have a Friday night off.

[Caraviello]: And Tom did that for probably 50 years.

[Caraviello]: until these kids got to be like 60.

[Caraviello]: They became older than us, but he was a tireless volunteer in the community, donated to everything.

[Caraviello]: I mean, he was that go-to guy for whatever he needed.

[Caraviello]: He wanted money with something.

[Caraviello]: Tom gave him money, he didn't never ever look for accolades or anything.

[Caraviello]: So like Councilman Scott mentioned in the past,

[Caraviello]: When guys like Tom die, nobody is stepping up to fill those shoes.

[Caraviello]: So Tom was a friend and these are a big set of shoes in the city that are gonna need to be filled.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, and on behalf of myself, thank you to the panel, thank you to everyone here.

[Caraviello]: So I would like to thank the chamber for hosting this debate, for all of you in attendance tonight, and for those of you watching from home.

[Caraviello]: My name is Rick Caraviello, and I'm running for mayor out of a genuine love and concern for our city, and I want to help keep Medford to be a great place to live, work, and raise a family.

[Caraviello]: I bring a consistent, transparent, and hands-on approach to Medford City government.

[Caraviello]: Too many of us know there's a distinct lack of vision coming out of City Hall.

[Caraviello]: Our economic growth lags behind neighboring communities.

[Caraviello]: Our schools are underperforming and lack proper safety protocols.

[Caraviello]: Our roads and sidewalks are in complete disrepair.

[Caraviello]: Too many critical positions in City Hall are left unfilled.

[Caraviello]: Our public employees are frustrated.

[Caraviello]: And our squares need to be reinvigorated.

[Caraviello]: I'm a 12-year veteran of the Medford City Council, serving as president for three times.

[Caraviello]: I have never been one to seek out the limelight.

[Caraviello]: I just get the job done.

[Caraviello]: As many of you said along the campaign trail, Rick answers the call.

[Caraviello]: And right now, people are calling me from across Medford, calling for new leadership.

[Caraviello]: One of my proudest public service accomplishments is bringing a new state-of-the-art public library to the city of Medford, along with being the co-chair of the Medford Public Library Foundation.

[Caraviello]: Another accomplishment was partnering with Councilor Marks, Arts Collaborative Medford, and Theory Wellness to deliver a long-awaited arts center that will offer a fresh, safe, and long-awaited center for Medford residents of all ages.

[Caraviello]: I understand what we need to move Metro forward.

[Caraviello]: And to do that, we need real leadership in the mayor's office.

[Caraviello]: And I am running for mayor for each and every one of you, whether you are a lifetime resident or just chose Metro to be your home now.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Number one priority would be filling vacancies that are in City Hall.

[Caraviello]: We have no city solicitor.

[Caraviello]: We have no building commissioner.

[Caraviello]: We have a part-time economic development director.

[Caraviello]: So those are my first three priorities as soon as I walk into office.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: So we talk about housing.

[Caraviello]: Why have we waited three years to get our 240B projects off the ground?

[Caraviello]: These are projects that should have been started three years ago.

[Caraviello]: They would have been probably been up now generating taxes and housing families.

[Caraviello]: So that's been an issue from day one.

[Caraviello]: I've agreed with the mayor, with all the housing authority, I've supported the walking club project, redoing all the 121 Riverside Avenue.

[Caraviello]: So we do need more housing because Medford is an unaffordable community.

[Caraviello]: And we need to do what we need to do to make Medford more affordable by providing more affordable housing.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: So the question is, do we support a new high school?

[Caraviello]: A high school is 52 years old.

[Caraviello]: I'm the second graduating class out of there.

[Caraviello]: Um, I was there last week talking to students,

[Caraviello]: And it looks the same as when I moved in there.

[Caraviello]: When we were on the council with the mayor, in the last 10 years, the state has given us millions of dollars to redo our science labs, our vocational school, and the pool, and different other projects there.

[Caraviello]: So with our declining enrollment at Medford High School, which is about 1,100 students,

[Caraviello]: I feel that there's room for improvement there.

[Caraviello]: I think we could shut down sections of the building, rehab them properly.

[Caraviello]: Because as I said, there's plenty of room.

[Caraviello]: The school was built for four to 5,000 students.

[Caraviello]: And we also have many other priorities.

[Caraviello]: We have a crumbling infrastructure.

[Caraviello]: We have a water and sewer system that I think we all agree that's ready to crumble over years in neglect.

[Caraviello]: We need roads, we need sidewalks.

[Caraviello]: This city needs a lot of things, and along with our fire station, that's been promised.

[Caraviello]: So we have to get out, before we start making decisions for $300 million, I think we need to sit and figure out what our real priorities are.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: The mayor's right, we have started doing it, but we started doing it now.

[Caraviello]: Where have we been the last couple of years when these projects should have been going on?

[Caraviello]: So yes, I agree with you, we're doing it now, and we're doing roads, and we're doing sidewalks, just too little too late.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: A new building will always bring new morale, but the children are taught from the teachers.

[Caraviello]: Those are the ones whose morale are low.

[Caraviello]: Those are the ones that need the help.

[Caraviello]: They're the ones that need the help.

[Caraviello]: So,

[Caraviello]: I'd love to see a new high school built, but I just think we need to bring our teachers in, give them the tools that they need to teach the students what they have to teach them, and they're the ones that'll bring the proficiency up, not a new building.

[Caraviello]: So a lot of my extra money we get comes from new growth in our community.

[Caraviello]: We need to push for new growth.

[Caraviello]: We need building permit fees.

[Caraviello]: These are the things, and new taxes, when buildings go up,

[Caraviello]: This is where we get the money to pay the raises.

[Caraviello]: And we shouldn't be waiting three years to negotiate contracts, because now we're looking for back pay to pay these people.

[Caraviello]: And they're signing contracts today, and next year they're up.

[Caraviello]: So we're not gaining any ground at all.

[Caraviello]: So my priority is to sit at the table in the beginning, not let them fester for two and three years, negotiate them soon, and give everybody a fair and equal contract.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Well, the mayor is the chief negotiator for our city, not KP Law.

[Caraviello]: The mayor should be at the table at the meetings negotiating, not an outside law firm.

[Caraviello]: This is an issue for me.

[Caraviello]: I've talked to teachers, I've talked to policemen, I've talked to firemen, and I've talked to other different groups.

[Caraviello]: They're tired of no one from the city showing up to represent them with an outside law firm doing the bulk of the negotiations.

[Caraviello]: I am the chief negotiator.

[Caraviello]: If I am mayor, I will sit there and I will negotiate contracts along with our in-house solicitor.

[Caraviello]: Our greatest challenge is making Medford affordable for families to live in.

[Caraviello]: As I said earlier, our housing costs are rising.

[Caraviello]: interest rates are rising, and people need to have places to live.

[Caraviello]: We have seniors who need to age in place, and they're struggling to decide whether I pay my rent or my house payments, or do I pay taxes.

[Caraviello]: So I want our seniors to age in place, and I want new families to be able to come here and live.

[Caraviello]: And I also want businesses to move here so their workers can live here also.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: For me, that's an easy one.

[Caraviello]: My proudest accomplishment is bringing the library to Medford.

[Caraviello]: I worked probably four years back and forth, finally to get them to come here, and they came, and under Mayor Burke,

[Caraviello]: She agreed to sit down and find the funding to get it done.

[Caraviello]: And I also am proud that I sit on the library foundation to help raise an additional $6 million to help fund that project.

[Caraviello]: So in a sense, in an essence- That's 30 seconds there.

[Caraviello]: In an essence, we own that library for almost 50 cents on the dollar, which is a steal.

[Caraviello]: So that's my proudest accomplishment.

[Caraviello]: As you know, the City of Medford is in the top five or six in what we're assessed for our services.

[Caraviello]: And over the years, we've been getting our services cut.

[Caraviello]: As many of you take the bus to work every day, you see the elimination of bus lines.

[Caraviello]: We now have a new train station at Medford that almost is working now, but the tracks don't work.

[Caraviello]: But the problem with that is

[Caraviello]: people that have disabilities have nowhere to park there.

[Caraviello]: And I've asked in the last few weeks to make sure that there's handicap parking for people there.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Well, as many of us know, we've just put in some new bike lanes and bump-outs throughout the city.

[Caraviello]: They're both good and bad.

[Caraviello]: They've helped safety, but they've also caused us to have major traffic problems, especially if you live in the West Medford area, you see the traffic in the morning backing up and down to the tracks, into Winchester and into the square because of the rotary that's there, and people can't get onto Route 16 to get to work.

[Caraviello]: So that's a giant one.

[Caraviello]: But I don't think what people don't realize is that part of the problem with that traffic is we have hundreds of thousands of rideshare rides that start in Medford.

[Caraviello]: And I think the Mayor can attest to this, that we get paid $0.10 for every rideshare that starts in Medford.

[Caraviello]: And I think last year we had over 300,000 rides that started here.

[Caraviello]: So you're putting cars on the road

[Caraviello]: with people that have no idea what this community is about.

[Caraviello]: They're driving by, their ways, and they're going through communities.

[Caraviello]: You have Grubhub now.

[Caraviello]: You've got Amazon trucks.

[Caraviello]: So we have, it isn't so much coming from our people, it's coming from outside sources that are coming to measure.

[Caraviello]: So that's really what we have to look at.

[Caraviello]: We could use more police at certain times of the day, helping with traffic.

[Caraviello]: So, like I said, we've been doing our bike lanes, and I wish more riders would take advantage of the bike lanes because I don't see many people in there.

[Caraviello]: So, again, I think the biggest problem comes from just too many cars on the road and not necessarily from people from MidFed.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: your streets can never be safe enough.

[Caraviello]: There's no, there's really no magic cure to get them done.

[Caraviello]: Um, we, we have a traffic engineer who needs to look at our, our traffic causing things as we've caused now, because what's happening is people are sitting in traffic, they're being frustrated and now they're going on to our side streets and which makes it even more dangerous.

[Caraviello]: And so our side streets are becoming cutthroats, uh, where people, uh,

[Caraviello]: are walking to school, and cars are racing through the neighborhood.

[Caraviello]: So I think we really need to figure out ways of fixing our traffic, along with getting people to use alternative means of transportation, bicycles, walkers, and things like that.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: So we talk about Bedford Square.

[Caraviello]: Since I've been on the council, I've seen multiple plans.

[Caraviello]: They all seem to be the same.

[Caraviello]: Some of them going back, I had one that went back to 2003, which is almost identical to the one we're putting out now.

[Caraviello]: We have a waterfront that other cities die for that really isn't talked to about in the plans up until recently.

[Caraviello]: We have housing.

[Caraviello]: that's in the square that could double in size, because the buildings, they're low, and you could get people to move into the square.

[Caraviello]: Part of our problem with our square talk is we always go out to committee.

[Caraviello]: We're always on committee and committee and committee, but we never, ever, ever

[Caraviello]: Go to the property owner and say, how can I help you develop your property?

[Caraviello]: What is your vision?

[Caraviello]: What do you want to see?

[Caraviello]: Everybody in this room has got great ideas for other people's property.

[Caraviello]: I want to talk to the property owners and see what they want to do with their property.

[Caraviello]: Let's find out how we can help them develop their property.

[Caraviello]: Let's give them some ideas.

[Caraviello]: This is how we invigorate the square.

[Caraviello]: I was with my wife over the summer in Melrose Center, and we stopped in the middle of the street, and I said to her, what do you see?

[Caraviello]: And she says, what are you talking about?

[Caraviello]: He says, look, stand in the middle.

[Caraviello]: I see a square lined with trees on both sides.

[Caraviello]: Look at our square.

[Caraviello]: It's full of concrete, it's barren, it's not friendly.

[Caraviello]: I want a warm, inviting square.

[Caraviello]: We have a Catalyst in Chevalier Auditorium that's bringing business in.

[Caraviello]: We finally have a new restaurant open.

[Caraviello]: Let's work with, if we had an economic development working full time, we'd have somebody that maybe could drive some more business into the square so we can get more restaurants and more businesses.

[Caraviello]: That's what we really need to do.

[Caraviello]: Similar to affordable housing,

[Caraviello]: Here we are, three and a half years later, and now we're starting the process of looking at what we need to do in the square.

[Caraviello]: Should have been started on day one.

[Caraviello]: That should have been a priority.

[Caraviello]: So why we have no development is our own fault because we're not out there trying to pull it in.

[Caraviello]: Well, when I was on the council, there was a proposal to put in a parking garage.

[Caraviello]: I was one of the four councilors who supported putting a parking garage in.

[Caraviello]: It needed five votes.

[Caraviello]: My question?

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: So on our current path, Medford is an unaffordable community.

[Caraviello]: You can ask any parent that has a child in daycare or a young family looking for an apartment to rent.

[Caraviello]: We need more affordable housing to support working families.

[Caraviello]: Our current administration stopped

[Caraviello]: our 40B projects.

[Caraviello]: I know we can give all the reasons why, but historically, the city does not prevail in those two cases in court, and we spent millions of dollars fighting them.

[Caraviello]: And we also need code enforcement to step up on our short-term rentals.

[Caraviello]: Airbnbs are becoming more and more prevalent in the city, which is becoming a problem.

[Caraviello]: People are taking good units off the market to make them essentially hotels.

[Caraviello]: And that's happening especially up in the Hillside area.

[Caraviello]: But now you're starting to see Airbnbs creeping into the neighborhood.

[Caraviello]: There's two in my neighborhood where I live, of single family.

[Caraviello]: So they're out there, and we have to figure out a way to fix those.

[Caraviello]: We have plans for our affordable housing, and they're a bit away.

[Caraviello]: I know we have a housing plan, but we don't have money to fund the housing plan, and that's a problem.

[Caraviello]: So I think we have to look for other means of funding to get more housing to come here.

[Caraviello]: And our housing authority is adding apartments on both Riverside Avenue and Walking Court.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: So we talk about new growth.

[Caraviello]: Look what's happened around us.

[Caraviello]: Look at Malden, thriving downtown.

[Caraviello]: Look at Somerville.

[Caraviello]: Look at Everett.

[Caraviello]: When did we become the poor sister to Malden and all these other communities?

[Caraviello]: Where's our new growth?

[Caraviello]: We keep talking about new growth, but all we see is little small things.

[Caraviello]: Downtown Malden has got a thriving

[Caraviello]: downtown with housing and restaurants and shopping.

[Caraviello]: That's what I want to see here.

[Caraviello]: Look at Everett.

[Caraviello]: Everett finally figured it out.

[Caraviello]: Developers are swarming Everett.

[Caraviello]: They still have cranes in the ground.

[Caraviello]: Every time you turn around, they're building new housing there.

[Caraviello]: Where is ours?

[Caraviello]: We've waited too long.

[Caraviello]: I mean, there's a lot of talk, but no action happening here.

[Caraviello]: I want to see shovels in the ground over the last three years, and we really haven't seen that.

[Caraviello]: Councilor, two minutes.

[Caraviello]: So I was one of the last two interviewed for the charter.

[Caraviello]: And one of my concerns for the charter committee was we made up a committee that did not reflect the community.

[Caraviello]: There was no one of color on the community.

[Caraviello]: Our largest growing population in the city of Mephit is Asian.

[Caraviello]: There was nobody from the Asian people there, nobody from the Haitian community.

[Caraviello]: It was a bunch of all white people.

[Caraviello]: And that's not what our community is made up of.

[Caraviello]: We're a diverse community and we didn't learn from the mistakes we made when we changed the name of the Columbus School to the Mississippi Tech School.

[Caraviello]: We put a committee together that didn't reflect the community.

[Caraviello]: So my opinion of the charter change, that's the will of the people.

[Caraviello]: If the people want the charter change, so be it.

[Caraviello]: One of the things I talked about in my interview was I thought that the council should have more power that they don't have.

[Caraviello]: I, for one, am not a proponent of ward representation.

[Caraviello]: I think you get bigger governments and less representation.

[Caraviello]: So childhood change does need to happen.

[Caraviello]: It's a long way away, and it's a long process.

[Caraviello]: But I think if we had a more diverse community, we would have got better questions than what we got.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: You mentioned all the diversity on the Charter Convention.

[Caraviello]: Maybe I didn't see those members in the group there.

[Caraviello]: So I apologize if I spoke out of turn, but that wasn't the group that I seemed to interview with.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: We have gotten better, but we're not good enough.

[Caraviello]: Our new growth is limited with developers talking instead of building.

[Caraviello]: the community, and those seeking to do business in our city, in order to bring the change that we need.

[Caraviello]: I'm also happy about disabled children being able to

[Caraviello]: use these facilities, which they've never been able to use before.

[Caraviello]: I'm real happy about that.

[Caraviello]: You know, as Councilor Bears mentioned, as we do with the library, as I look at these pictures here, this is a plethora of naming rights, businesses, and things like that.

[Caraviello]: I mean, if I were you, I would form a foundation similar to like the library did.

[Caraviello]: You've got like, now you get, okay.

[Caraviello]: The library, we sold everything.

[Caraviello]: Anybody that wants a paper, we gave you something, we put your name on it.

[Caraviello]: And like I said, from big rooms to chairs to the smallest thing, people are willing to donate.

[Caraviello]: We're a very generous community.

[Caraviello]: And like I said, you've got like this little park here.

[Caraviello]: I'm sure you'll find a family that might want to name it after someone in their family.

[Caraviello]: You've got the house here.

[Caraviello]: You've got all these things that you could put naming rights on

[Caraviello]: Be surprised, be surprised how much, how generous people are when you go to ask them.

[Caraviello]: There's businesses, there's foundations, there's anonymous families that just, they do want to help.

[Caraviello]: So I encourage you to maybe form a, I'd be more than happy to help you figure out how to form a private foundation to help raise some private money.

[Caraviello]: to, you know, like I say, just cuts down the cost of city, but people take pride in this when they see these things.

[Caraviello]: And like I said, they like to see their name.

[Caraviello]: Businesses want to see their names on things.

[Caraviello]: They want people to know that they're part of the community.

[Caraviello]: So I think, you know, you've got a good start here.

[Caraviello]: And I say, you know, you can do this with this.

[Caraviello]: And, you know, as you move on, you know, naming rights for things that just, let's say,

[Caraviello]: are a great thing to do, so I apologize for what you're doing.

[Caraviello]: But especially with the part about the trauma, because I say, I am with a group, and that is what they do, specializes in the head trauma for kids, and they also help design playgrounds for kids so they don't get hurt.

[Caraviello]: So now I am demanding adequate resources, security, to help keep our students safe.

[Caraviello]: First off, let's get one thing straight.

[Caraviello]: Stabbing yesterday was not an isolated incident.

[Caraviello]: Bullying has been going on for a long time at that high school.

[Caraviello]: Didn't just start yesterday.

[Caraviello]: A gun clip found in a middle school auditorium during a school vacation was an isolated incident.

[Caraviello]: No one was hurt.

[Caraviello]: Gun clips by themselves don't hurt people, but knives and physical violence do.

[Caraviello]: Everyone who engages in the community could see this coming a mile away.

[Caraviello]: Bullying has been escalated, unchecked, since the start of the school year.

[Caraviello]: But rather than address the situation on early

[Caraviello]: school officials, superintendent, school committee, and the mayor consistently downplayed each and every incident, hoping it would go away.

[Caraviello]: It was unconscionable that no comment, acknowledgement, or plan of action was implemented immediately.

[Caraviello]: What are we thinking?

[Caraviello]: We all know when people aren't thinking.

[Caraviello]: Yesterday's school committee was another pointless charade of the council needs to work together and not yell at us.

[Caraviello]: Let me tell you something.

[Caraviello]: I've been working here for 11 years.

[Caraviello]: I've gotten yelled at many times.

[Caraviello]: If you can't take getting yelled at, then don't run for office.

[Caraviello]: I've been willing to work together with any elected body since the first day I was elected.

[Caraviello]: People are justifiably angry.

[Caraviello]: It's become quite clear that when the teachers had a vote of no confidence, it was directed to the school committee and the mayor's chair.

[Caraviello]: I'm tired of seeing my city, Medford, in the media recently with a glaring negative spotlight now focused on our community.

[Caraviello]: It's evident that we're not ready for this prime time.

[Caraviello]: I was astonished to hear our superintendent say on television last night, we don't encourage bringing weapons to school, encourage.

[Caraviello]: Statement I find boggles, say at least.

[Caraviello]: Do you want, and don't worry, you won't get kicked out of school.

[Caraviello]: After all, everyone is entitled to an education.

[Caraviello]: That's not a surprise to me here either.

[Caraviello]: The seams are coming apart.

[Caraviello]: There's patchwork on different parts.

[Caraviello]: What's the difference between Winchester and Medford?

[Caraviello]: If they did it at night, it wasn't that, we're not talking no major overhaul here or anything.

[Caraviello]: So no one answered my question.

[Caraviello]: I want a name of a person.

[Caraviello]: And if I recall, there was some company out of Connecticut that was hired.

[Caraviello]: Going forward, you talked about speed tables.

[Caraviello]: So I noticed there's one up right in Winter Street, or right where the road splits.

[Caraviello]: Where is the next one planned for?

[Caraviello]: Victory Park is after the school.

[Caraviello]: And I thank you for working on the, I think that more important to me is for the last three years, I've asked for the legal bills of this community.

[Caraviello]: We have so few World War II veterans left in our country.

[Caraviello]: Then Frank Mills was 101 years old and served this country with a pride

[Caraviello]: and World War II, and not only did he serve his country, he served his community for many years.

[Caraviello]: He was a resident here for 72 years.

[Caraviello]: He was a coach at St.

[Caraviello]: Joseph's in baseball and basketball.

[Caraviello]: Actually, what is the private way in the services that private ways are entitled to people live on private ways.

[Caraviello]: don't pay any less taxes than the people on the public way, and they deserve the same services that everyone else gets.

[Caraviello]: what gets done on a private way.

[Caraviello]: And actually, most people don't even know what a private way is.

[Caraviello]: You have a lot of new people moving into the community.

[Caraviello]: I think they don't even understand what it is.

[Caraviello]: Let's say the city should be doing everything that it does on everyone else's street.

[Caraviello]: They shouldn't get less.

[Caraviello]: You got two parcels on Canal Street.

[Caraviello]: that are ripe for a small development.

[Caraviello]: You've got a parcel on Harvard Avenue, ripe for development, and you've got some buildings there that can maybe add another floor or two.

[Caraviello]: So I'm asking the mayor to appoint a task force, but I want the task force to be the property owners, the stakeholders in the game.

[Caraviello]: You know, what we do in this community is we appoint these committees and these commissions, and they all go out with these great ideas for other people's property, and we never go out and talk to the property owners.

[Caraviello]: I want this task force to be the property owners.

[Caraviello]: Let's see what we can do for them.

[Caraviello]: What is it going to take them to upgrade their property?

[Caraviello]: What kind of development?

[Caraviello]: How can we help them get funding?

[Caraviello]: So again, this is an easy, it's an easy task force they can build.

[Caraviello]: I've already talked to some of the property owners down there that they're interested in getting on board.

[Caraviello]: So if they make it, do that.

[Caraviello]: But I say, I'm asking that the task force be with the property owners and get them on board.

[Caraviello]: Let's see what we can do and get that part of the town moving.

[Caraviello]: Let's get rid of those empty stores there.

[Caraviello]: and bring some people down there and bring business down there.

[Caraviello]: Again, businesses want to come where there's people and there's no people, there's no walking traffic down there.

[Caraviello]: So, I'll wait for any of my other councilors to have any discussion on that.

[Caraviello]: Motion approved.

[Caraviello]: And if the city, and I talked to Victor today about this, if our group, if our board can help them either get funding or give them some ideas of what to do.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Madam President, as I think the motion speaks for itself and we've had a distinguished history of our military in your.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Okay, 22-010 offered by Councilor Biz be resolved by the Medford City Council.

[Caraviello]: The rules of the Medford City Council be updated to strike the following meetings.

[Caraviello]: Rule two, regular meetings of the City Council shall be held weekly on Tuesday evening at seven o'clock

[Caraviello]: in the PM, except there shall be one meeting during the months of July and August, and there shall be at least two meetings in September.

[Caraviello]: They shall be held in Council Chambers, and replaced it with meetings.

[Caraviello]: Rule two, regular meetings of the City Council should be held every two weeks on Tuesday evening at seven o'clock PM, beginning on the first Tuesday in January, and there shall only be one meeting during the months of July and August.

[Caraviello]: Meetings shall be held in Council Chambers.

[Caraviello]: Meetings of the Committee of the Whole shall be scheduled by the Council President.

[Caraviello]: meetings of subcommittees shall be scheduled by the subcommittee chairperson.

[Caraviello]: Scheduling preference of the meetings of the committees and subcommittees shall be on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings, beginning at six o'clock PM.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, city council and the council.

[Caraviello]: I respectfully request or recommend that your Honorable Body approve and authorize the grant of an easement to the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation.

[Caraviello]: The purpose of this easement is to install, construct, operate, maintain, repair, reconstruct, and replace a public recreation non-motorized bike trail and pedestrian trail.

[Caraviello]: For your information, I am submitting a copy of the document containing the proposed grant of easement along with a plan setting for the area.

[Caraviello]: All those in favor?

[Caraviello]: Communications from the mayor. 21630.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President and Councilors, I respectfully request and recommend that the City Council approves the following five-year contracts after a three-quote process conducted by the parking director for a parking data management system in a truck-car rental lease.

[Caraviello]: It is the intention of the City to enter a five-year agreement with GT Techno USA Corporation in enterprise fleet management

[Caraviello]: Inc.

[Caraviello]: Master General Laws Chapter 30B, Section 12 requires that the City Council approval for a contract that exceeds three years, which is why we come before you today.

[Caraviello]: So, Amendment 1.

[Caraviello]: Allow the city and the Department of Parking to enter into a five-year lease agreement for the acquisition of vehicles for the purpose of collecting money in enforcing parking rules within the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: Please see the attached copy of the presentation materials.

[Caraviello]: Amendment two, agreement two.

[Caraviello]: Allow the city and the Department of Parking to enter into a five-year contract to acquire

[Caraviello]: the data management systems and how we're required to collect monies, enforce parking rules, manage permit parking program, and administer the appeals process.

[Caraviello]: Please see the attached for a copy of the quotation.

[Caraviello]: The above request is made in five year time periods because that is the most cost effective procedure.

[Caraviello]: It also allows for a long-term planning as a new parking department is formed and developed.

[Caraviello]: I respectfully request to recommend that your own body, pursuant to the provisions of national law, chapter 30B, section 12, approves and authorize the city of Medford-DeWinter into agreement with the above-mentioned vendors for five years.
