[Caraviello]: 21619 off of my Vice President Knight and President Caraviello, be it so resolved that the Medford City Council thank the Sloan family and all of the Century Bank staff for their philanthropy and contributions to the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: Vice President Knight.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Personally, I've known the Sloan family for many years.

[Caraviello]: Marshall Sloan, a citizen of the year.

[Caraviello]: Barry and his sister have been great community members.

[Caraviello]: Their philanthropy throughout the community has been second to none.

[Caraviello]: Their room at the top of the bank, they gave to everybody that used, paid for everyone's dinners there.

[Caraviello]: I mean, let's say,

[Caraviello]: The family who started with a small bank in Somerville and grown to one of the largest banks in New England, privately held.

[Caraviello]: And again, I talked to Barry all the time and I wished him well personally, but again, I wanna wish everybody, Barry and his whole family, great success on whatever him and Linda decided to do going forward.

[Caraviello]: And we welcome Eastern Bank into our community and hope they'll be the same kind of partner that the Sloans were.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: So, on the motion by Vice President Knight, seconded by Councilor Falco.

[Caraviello]: All those in favor?

[Caraviello]: Motion passes.

[Caraviello]: 21622 offered by Councilor Morell, whereas lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death among men and women in the United States and in Massachusetts 2021, accounting for more deaths than colon cancer, breast cancer, prostate cancer combined, whereas according to the Massachusetts Centers for Disease Control, there were 5,500 deaths.

[Caraviello]: 50 new lung cancer cases and 2770 deaths caused by lung cancer in 2021.

[Caraviello]: And whereas the five year survival rate for localized lung cancer is minus 59%, yet only 17% of lung cancers are diagnosed at this stage.

[Caraviello]: And whereas funding for lung cancer cancer trails far behind

[Caraviello]: funding for research of many other cancers and additional research is needed early diagnosis screening and treatment for lung cancer, as well as lung cancer affecting women in lung cancer health disparities ends, whereas African Americans have the highest lung cancer

[Caraviello]: Incidents in mortality of all races and disparities and like cancer screening diagnosis treatment in mortality.

[Caraviello]: I will carry characterize among African Americans and other racial minorities and whereas lung cancer, and never smokers is a seven pleasing cause of cancer related deaths in accounts for 17,000 to 26,000 deaths in the US every year, 60 to 70%.

[Caraviello]: of never smokers diagnosed with lung cancer are women in a proportion of lung cancers diagnosed in never smokers is increasing in the United States.

[Caraviello]: Therefore, be it so resolved that the Medford City Council recognize November 2021 as Lung Cancer Awareness Month in Medford and encourages all citizens to learn about lung cancer and early detection through lung cancer screening.

[Caraviello]: And I'd like to maybe have him come here maybe next week to receive a citation from our city council chair recognizes Councilmarks.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. President done.

[Caraviello]: As you know, we've been struggling with this ever source project for going on four or five years now.

[Caraviello]: And with the paving so I think many of us have been.

[Caraviello]: I think we, we went a little bit dodging the manhole covers all over Mr. gab we got that paved.

[Caraviello]: Now, we're still dodging manhole covers on South Street.

[Caraviello]: The neighbors have received a letter that this street was supposed to have been paid a month ago.

[Caraviello]: As of today there's still no paving.

[Caraviello]: I think, as we all know, as the weather gets colder, the asphalt plants will be closing down soon.

[Caraviello]: So are we going to wait until the asphalt plant closes down and we buy asphalt of serious standard, just the kind they use to do patchwork, or is this going to get done in a reasonable amount of time?

[Caraviello]: Again, we have one of the neighbors here that lives on South Street, and they say, these neighbors have been promised this for going on a while now.

[Caraviello]: They say they were a month overdue.

[Caraviello]: No.

[Caraviello]: OK.

[Caraviello]: Well, I'll say, again, we'd like to get an update in when this pavement is going to get done on South Street.

[Caraviello]: Never mind.

[Caraviello]: And if you go to Prescott Street, they've dug up streets over there with trenches, and they didn't even patch them.

[Caraviello]: They filled them in with dirt.

[Caraviello]: Again, we're gonna wait till the plane closes, and we're gonna be using the winter mix that lasts about a month, and then it's gone again.

[Caraviello]: I mean, there's not even anybody down there working anymore on Prescott Street.

[Caraviello]: In fact, I had a call to the engineer last week, because during all that rain, there was a hole that you can drive your car fell into.

[Caraviello]: So again, these are projects that, this Eversource project is never gonna end, ever.

[Caraviello]: I mean, it's just going, and you say, now that, I mean, they're still digging in front of the police station now every night, and you're seeing plates and plates, and now we're getting the complaints from the neighbors as the plates have moved down on that end now.

[Caraviello]: I say, I would think at some point, we need to get Eversource in here,

[Caraviello]: and figure out where they're going.

[Caraviello]: I mean, they're going a couple of feet a day.

[Caraviello]: This project isn't going anywhere.

[Caraviello]: We're probably another two years away from this project getting done.

[Caraviello]: So I would make a motion that we have a community of the whole meeting with the Eversource officials, whether it be, I think it's Robin Collins, she's the project manager.

[Caraviello]: to get somebody in here at the committee hall to discuss where the project is going and have the engineer reach out to the people doing the work on Prescott Street by the school.

[Caraviello]: Get your hand out of his back, Zach.

[Caraviello]: I don't know who's doing Prescott Street, but I haven't seen them down there in a bit.

[Caraviello]: I think it is McCabe.

[Caraviello]: I'm not sure.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Council Member.

[Caraviello]: And on my motion, I've got concerns about the paving that was already done.

[Caraviello]: Um, it's already coming up in some spots you can you can see the, you can see there's no seals around the edges and say it's a, my opinion, it's shoddy work at best.

[Caraviello]: And they say, if this is the way they're gonna do it, it's not right.

[Caraviello]: I mean, they paved in the, it's raining all week.

[Caraviello]: Who paves in the rain?

[Caraviello]: I went up and looked at paving statutes,

[Caraviello]: says you shouldn't be paving when you know there's going to be three, four or five days of rain, because it never cures.

[Caraviello]: To make it up to the where it should be the same status because at the end when it comes up, who's going to fit the bill for us, it's gonna be the taxpayers in the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: According to what I read, it says that the road should be dry for at least two days.

[Caraviello]: Yes, yep.

[Caraviello]: Trucks going down it all day and night.

[Caraviello]: And with skimping on the hot tub.

[Caraviello]: It's not even sealed around the edges.

[Caraviello]: Tim, not acceptable.

[Caraviello]: We're not going to get blamed for this.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Morocco.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Falco.

[Caraviello]: So we're going from one end of the street to the other end of the street, which is

[Caraviello]: on the corner of Prescott and Austin.

[Caraviello]: I think you brought this up a couple of weeks ago about all the equipment that was left there.

[Caraviello]: Well, it was gone for about a week.

[Caraviello]: Now the backhoe is back there and the other things are back there.

[Caraviello]: But my concern is on the corner of Austin and Prescott, Newport Construction has decided to park a trailer blocking the whole sidewalk and along with putting backhoe parts on there.

[Caraviello]: And right down the street is senior housing.

[Caraviello]: So bad enough they can't walk on the street because the street's all dug up and now they can't even walk on the sidewalk.

[Caraviello]: I did call the engineer on Friday and I asked him to have them immediately remove it.

[Caraviello]: I don't know what he did, but obviously it's still there.

[Caraviello]: I did call the code enforcement officer to have it removed, still there.

[Caraviello]: So I think at this point,

[Caraviello]: I don't know what the next course of action is.

[Caraviello]: It's been sitting there since last week.

[Caraviello]: And I see the seniors that are walking now, they're walking in the middle of a broken up street.

[Caraviello]: So it's just not fair.

[Caraviello]: And again, it has to be removed immediately.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. Vice President.

[Caraviello]: 2-1-595, offered by Vice President Knight.

[Caraviello]: City of Medford, call for a municipal election Tuesday, November 2nd, 2021.

[Caraviello]: Be it ordered that in accordance with provisions of general laws of Massachusetts and the revised charter of the city of Medford, and so far as the latter is applicable, the city clerk be, and he is hereby authorized and instructed to notify in one such of the inhabitants of the city of Medford qualified to vote and as the law

[Caraviello]: requires to assemble at several polling places as designated in this order for and within several precincts where they are duly registered voters on Tuesday, November 2nd, 2021, then and there to give their ballots for election of respectively.

[Caraviello]: One, mayor of the city of Medford to serve a period of two years from the first Monday in January, 2022 to be elected by and from the qualified voters of the city of Medford at large.

[Caraviello]: seven members of the Medford City Council to serve a period of two years from the first Monday in January, 2022, to be elected by and from the qualified voters of the city of Bedford-at-Large, six members of the Medford School Committee to serve for a period of two years from the first Monday in January, 2022, to be elected by and from the qualified voters of the city at large, and be it further ordered that the following name polling places be and they

[Caraviello]: Um, where do I, where do I go with my house?

[Caraviello]: I move out of the community can't say near the other otherwise say I say well, but a lot of people want to understand this when you reach a certain age like I am you know the advice that you're given is to take the house out of your name and put in your children's name.

[Caraviello]: So in the event you go into a nursing home or something like that, so these people are no longer eligible for the senior tax rate anymore.

[Caraviello]: So everybody forgets about that.

[Caraviello]: And there's a lot of people in the community that, yes, they're living in, you know, you're living out,

[Caraviello]: You know, they've turned the house over to the children because in the event they have to go into a nursing home or something, they don't want to lose their home.

[Caraviello]: But now they're no longer eligible for the tax breaks that seniors get.

[Caraviello]: And people seem to forget that, let's say.

[Caraviello]: I'm the, uh, I'm the senior citizens up here now.

[Caraviello]: I, you know, I, you know, and, uh, and I, I'm hearing advice that I'm being given what to do with my house, you know, things like that.

[Caraviello]: So please take that in mind that when we talk about, uh, giving the breaks, the people that live in the house that really don't own the house anymore.

[Caraviello]: So that's, that's, that's part of the problem too.

[Caraviello]: This is a matter that's come to my attention.

[Caraviello]: A lot of residents and I live in that neighborhood.

[Caraviello]: If anyone is driven by Vernon Street, you'll see that they're in the process of currently putting in a new sidewalks, some new curbing and the paving the street.

[Caraviello]: So, for those of you aren't familiar, Vernon Street is kind of cut in half.

[Caraviello]: I'd say it goes on the Mystic Street end versus the All Street end.

[Caraviello]: So one half of the street has granite curbing.

[Caraviello]: The other half of the street, from what I'm told, was supposed to have granite curbing, and either the contractor wasn't able to get it, so they've decided to put in a concrete curb.

[Caraviello]: And anyone knows how good a concrete curb is.

[Caraviello]: One plow hits it, it's pretty much done.

[Caraviello]: But that's not so much the issue of the concrete curb.

[Caraviello]: The issue is you have historic homes there, and this is not the type of curbing that belongs in front of historic homes.

[Caraviello]: Everyone else in the city has granite curbs.

[Caraviello]: These residents deserve the same curbing as everybody else.

[Caraviello]: So I would motion that we have the city engineer

[Caraviello]: give us a report on why they don't have curbing.

[Caraviello]: I know he said they couldn't get it.

[Caraviello]: I don't know why they can't get it.

[Caraviello]: Everyone else seems to have curbing.

[Caraviello]: But it would be my motion to not pave that section of Vernon Street until a decision is made whether to put granite curbs in, because these people deserve it and their house, everyone else has it, versus the concrete curbing that is in the neighborhood now.

[Caraviello]: I'm sorry, I'm sorry, you can run them in.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, I think we have some people in the audience who are in the neighborhood that may wanna speak.

[Caraviello]: Excellent, Mr. Chair, I recognize Councilor Morell.

[Caraviello]: Chair recognizes Councilor Caraviello.

[Caraviello]: The sidewalks have to be put down all over the place.

[Caraviello]: And so again, I don't think the work can't continue.

[Caraviello]: They can pave some of, they can pave the Austin Street, I mean, excuse me, the Brooks part of, Brooks Street section of Austin, of Vernon Street, plenty of things there.

[Caraviello]: Hey, I'm sorry to speak.

[Caraviello]: Good evening, name and address of the record, please.

[Caraviello]: I do not see one on the call.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: I came in on Monday, and I did have an opportunity to meet Mr. Chamalia and introduce myself and told him I'd be here to assist.

[Caraviello]: And left, and I didn't know how long, I don't know how long he was in the building.

[Caraviello]: We did have an emergency situation this morning, which a family reached out to me because City Hall hadn't been open.

[Caraviello]: And I did reach out to Mr. Somalia with the people's number to help them out.

[Caraviello]: And when I reached out, reached back up to the family, he had helped them.

[Caraviello]: But it doesn't constitute us not having somebody in the building.

[Caraviello]: So this woman, this family could have came in here, we didn't have to do this on the phone.

[Caraviello]: It was a very traumatic thing.

[Caraviello]: And let's say, though I do appreciate him helping out,

[Caraviello]: I think that was something that should have been done in person because of the seriousness of the nature of what happened to the family.

[Caraviello]: No.

[Caraviello]: Line item 1 0 1, 1, 5, 1, 5, 0, 3, 2 contract legal services.

[Caraviello]: Fiscal year 2022 budget amount was $26,600.

[Caraviello]: Proposed amended amounts $81,600.

[Caraviello]: Following the passage of the

[Caraviello]: fiscal year 2022 budget by the council.

[Caraviello]: I engaged in conversations with Council President Caraviello, City Solicitor Kim Scanlon, and KP Law to develop a process where the council can avail themselves to KP Law services and Councilors needed.

[Caraviello]: Okay, 21548, September 10th, 2021.

[Caraviello]: Personnel loadings, dear Mr. President and councilors, I respectfully request or recommend that city council approve the following amendments to the revised ordinance entitled, Personal Act Article II, Classification and Compensation Plan, section 66-33, entitled, Officers, Employees, Non-Union Adopting by Adopting the Following Changes.

[Caraviello]: Amendment A,

[Caraviello]: The language of CAF 11 shall be amended to include the following position, assistant purchasing agent.

[Caraviello]: Amendment B, the language of CAF 12 shall be amended to include the following position, land use planner.

[Caraviello]: Amendment C, the language of CAF 13 shall be amended to include the following position, MCM station manager.

[Caraviello]: Amendment D,

[Caraviello]: The language of CAF 3 shall be amended to include the following position, MCM production coordinator.

[Caraviello]: Please note that the above included positions are those that have been discovered to have been created previously, but not included within the compensation plan.

[Caraviello]: Additional positions may be added to the existing compensation plan following the upcoming compensation plan salary study being undertaken by the city through the community compact grant program.

[Caraviello]: We respectfully submitted Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Caraviello]: Learn from the mistake we made the first time rolling it out in the middle of the winter.

[Caraviello]: People figure it out.

[Caraviello]: City of Medford call for a preliminary election Tuesday, September 14th, 2021.

[Caraviello]: be it ordered that in accordance with the provisions of the general laws of Massachusetts and the revised charter of the city of Medford insofar as the latter is applicable, the city clerk be and he is hereby authorized and instructed to notify and warn such of the inhabitants

[Caraviello]: of the city of Medford qualified to vote and as the law requires to assemble at the several polling places as designated in this order and within several precincts where they are duly registered voters on Tuesday, September 14, 2020.

[Caraviello]: Then and there to give their ballots for the nomination of respectively.

[Caraviello]: six members of the Method School Committee to serve for a period of two years from the first Monday in January 2022 to be elected by and from the qualified voters of the city at large, and one mayor of the city of Medford to serve for a period of two years from the first Monday in January 2022 to be elected from the qualified voters of the city at large.

[Caraviello]: To President Caraviello and members of Medford City Council, registered voters at Inverter Beach Clerk, early in mail voting, date August 12th,

[Caraviello]: 2021.

[Caraviello]: On July 29, Governor Baker signed Chapter 29 of the Acts of 2021 among the items that the legislation extends early voting by mail for all elections through December 15 of this year.

[Caraviello]: The legislation also allows the City Council to designate

[Caraviello]: in-person early voting for any election upon request or recommendation of the local election official.

[Caraviello]: Within the parameters of the legislation, I am requesting and recommending four days of in-person early voting leading into the preliminary municipal election on September 14th.

[Caraviello]: And I am requesting and recommending five days of in-person early voting leading into the municipal election on November 2nd.

[Caraviello]: For the preliminary municipal election on September 14th, I am requesting and recommending that you designate the following four days and times for in-person early voting.

[Caraviello]: Tuesday, September 7th, 8.30 a.m.

[Caraviello]: to 4.30 p.m., normal city hall business hours.

[Caraviello]: Wednesday, September 8th, 8.30 a.m.

[Caraviello]: to 7.30 p.m., normal city hall business hours.

[Caraviello]: Thursday, September 9th, 8.30 a.m.

[Caraviello]: 4.30 p.m.

[Caraviello]: normal city hall business hours.

[Caraviello]: Friday, September 10th, 8.30 a.m.

[Caraviello]: to 12.30 p.m.

[Caraviello]: normal city hall business hours.

[Caraviello]: All in-person early voting would occur as with past practice in the city council chambers.

[Caraviello]: For the municipal election on November 2, I am requesting and recommending that you designate the following five days in time for in-person early voting again in the city

[Caraviello]: Council Chambers.

[Caraviello]: Saturday, October 23rd, nine o'clock a.m.

[Caraviello]: to five o'clock p.m.

[Caraviello]: Saturday voting.

[Caraviello]: Monday, October 25th, 8.30 a.m.

[Caraviello]: to 4.30 p.m.

[Caraviello]: Normal City Hall Business Hours.

[Caraviello]: Tuesday, October 26th, 8.30 a.m.

[Caraviello]: to 4.30 p.m.

[Caraviello]: Normal City Hall Business Hours.

[Caraviello]: Wednesday,

[Caraviello]: October 27th, 8.30 a.m.

[Caraviello]: to 7.30 p.m., normal city hall business hours.

[Caraviello]: Thursday, October 28th, 8.30 a.m.

[Caraviello]: to 4.30 p.m., normal city hall business hours.

[Caraviello]: For both elections, in-person early voting can begin not less than 10 days before the election and must end no later than the business day before the business day preceding the election.

[Caraviello]: Following a duly advertised public hearing conducted on July 21, 2021, the Community Development Board voted to recommend that the Medford City Council adopt the proposed amendment to change the structure of the Medford Zoning Board of Appeals from three members and one associate to five members and two associate members.

[Caraviello]: The board recommends that the council consider reincorporating language related to staggering terms

[Caraviello]: that is present in the existing ordinance by inserting the following second sentence after the phrase, term of three years, which shall be staggered so that terms of not more than two members expire annually.

[Caraviello]: 2-1, 4-2-2, petition for a grant of location, 257 Spring Street Citizen Bank, doing business as ADA upgrades.

[Caraviello]: You are hereby notified that by order of the Medford City Council, a continued public hearing will be given by a Zoom and in-person in Howard F. Alden Memorial Chambers on the second floor of Medford City Council, 85 George B. Assett Drive, at seven o'clock on Tuesday, August 17th,

[Caraviello]: 2020, a link posted no later than Friday, August 13th, 2021, on a petition of LR Construction, Inc., on behalf of the Citizens Bank, for permission to construct the proposed ADA upgrades at 257 Spring Street, Citizens Bank.

[Caraviello]: Proposed plans have been filed in the office of the city clerk.

[Caraviello]: Wherefore, it prays that after the due notice and hearing,

[Caraviello]: by law, they'd be granted permission to complete the project in accordance with the plans available for inspection in the office of the City Clerk of the City Hall room 103 George Piazza Drive, FMS 02155.

[Caraviello]: The entire scope of this project includes ABA upgrades of three locations.

[Caraviello]: front ATM vestibule and lobby, rear parking lot, and the front entrance along Spring Street.

[Caraviello]: The work at the front entrance includes modifying city sidewalks.

[Caraviello]: The scope of the work at the front entrance is as follows.

[Caraviello]: Demo existing sidewalks in three sections along the building, 108 square feet, install a new ADA compliant landing and ramp,

[Caraviello]: install a new EDA compliant handrail around landing along the ramp.

[Caraviello]: Approved city engineer with the following conditions, recommendations.

[Caraviello]: One, the engineering division provided a suggested process to assist the city council in our October 21, 2020 memo.

[Caraviello]: As indicated in that process, if approved by the city council,

[Caraviello]: the petitioner would be required to draft a proposed licensing agreement in coordination with the legal department and engineering division.

[Caraviello]: The engineering division recommends that the city council determine if this process is adequate and reasonable pursuant to section 74-63 of the city ordinances.

[Caraviello]: Two, the engineering division recommends that existing encroachments be allowed to remain so situated

[Caraviello]: for as long as they remain in good condition.

[Caraviello]: If they fall into disrepair or poor conditions, the city will revoke the license.

[Caraviello]: The existing encroachments will include a metal fire escape, building cornices, and signs attached to the building three.

[Caraviello]: The easement plan indicates an easement area that extends beyond the existing projections into the public way, the engineering division.

[Caraviello]: takes no exception to this approach.

[Caraviello]: However, the license agreement should indicate that no new encroachments or expansion of the existing encroachments is allowed beyond the limits of the existing encroachments as shown on the eastern plan.

[Caraviello]: Four,

[Caraviello]: The license agreement should indicate that the licensee will maintain the encroaching items in good condition.

[Caraviello]: Five, the license agreement should indicate that the city will revoke the license upon removal of the encroaching items.

[Caraviello]: Six, the city council should decide if the license agreement should include a renewal period or expiration.

[Caraviello]: Seven, the city council should recommend a reasonable fee be charged by the city for use of public property for the benefit of the petitioner.

[Caraviello]: The licensed area must include the level landing at the base of the ramp.

[Caraviello]: Nine, the license agreement should acknowledge that the potential presence of underground utilities beneath the proposed ramp should not restrict access to these utilities.

[Caraviello]: 10, the notification for the public hearing regarding this approval process should include utility companies that have infrastructure in this block of Spring Street.

[Caraviello]: 11, the sidewalk work associated with this ramp is adjacent to a cracked sidewalk panels.

[Caraviello]: adjacent crack panels should be replaced.

[Caraviello]: 12, the ramp is a projection of the building and is associated with the building.

[Caraviello]: Entrance and exit.

[Caraviello]: The ramp must be built per applicable building code and inspected by the building department for code compliance.

[Caraviello]: 13, the plan indicates a national grid manhole near the proposed ramp.

[Caraviello]: The licensee should not restrict access to this manhole.

[Caraviello]: The plan indicates relocating a tree pit on Spring Street that conflicts with clearances needed for the ramp.

[Caraviello]: The new location appears reasonable and should be confirmed with the tree ward.

[Caraviello]: 15, the license agreement should indicate the minimum clearance between the ramp and the front of the curb to be 72 inches.

[Caraviello]: Call 781-393-2425 for any further accommodations.

[Caraviello]: Do we have any discussion on this?

[Caraviello]: The petitioner is on call.

[Caraviello]: Where is the petitioner?

[Caraviello]: Ammar Salam?

[Caraviello]: Can you hold on one second?

[Caraviello]: 27th regular meeting of the Medford City Council.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: All rise and salute the flag.

[Caraviello]: Motion by Vice President Knight to suspend the rules to take paper 21-541 out of order.

[Caraviello]: All those in favor?

[Caraviello]: Seconded by Councilor Falco.

[Caraviello]: All those in favor?

[Caraviello]: Motion passes.

[Caraviello]: Dear Mr. Presidents and Councilors, I respectfully request and recommend that the City Council approve the following amendments to the revised ordinance titled

[Caraviello]: Compensation plans in Lee Borden's Chapter 66 personnel.

[Caraviello]: This amendment is requested due to a recently negotiated agreement with the Teamsters Local 25 covering employees from three departments.

[Caraviello]: It is estimated that the contract will cost approximately $288,920.92 in retroactive funds.

[Caraviello]: This contract for which negotiations began in 2019 is the first covering the affected employees.

[Caraviello]: A request for transfer of the funds to the affected apartments will be submitted to the city council under a separate cover.

[Caraviello]: Sincerely yours, Brianna Lungo, current mayor.

[Caraviello]: be it ordained that the City Council of the City of Medford in Chapter 66, Entitled Personnel Article Two, Entitled Classification Compensation Plans, Section 66, Act 4-0, is hereby amended by inserting the following new section.

[Caraviello]: I'll try it here.

[Caraviello]: be it further ordained that the positions outlined herein be removed from the current classification as they appear in the current classification compensation plan.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: Any discussion on this?

[Caraviello]: on Tuesday, July 13th.

[Caraviello]: The link will be posted no later than Friday, June 9th, on a petition of L.R.

[Caraviello]: Construction on behalf of Citizens Bank for permission to construct ADA upgrades at 257 Spring Street, Citizens Bank,

[Caraviello]: Proposed plans have been filed in the Office of the City Clerk.

[Caraviello]: We are therefore appraised that after a due notice and a hearing provided by law that they be granted permission to complete the project in accordance with the plans available for inspection of the Office of the City Clerk, Medford City Hall, from 103-85 George P. Hassell Drive, FMS.

[Caraviello]: The entire scope of this project includes ADA upgrades in three locations, front ATM vestibule and lobby, rear parking lot, front entrance along Spring Street,

[Caraviello]: The work at the front entrance includes modifying city sidewalks.

[Caraviello]: The scope of the work at the front entrance is as follows.

[Caraviello]: Demo existing sidewalks, three sections along the building, total of 108 square feet.

[Caraviello]: Install new ADA compliant landing and ramp.

[Caraviello]: Install a new ADA compliant handrail around the landing ramp.

[Caraviello]: approved by the chief engineer with the following conditions.

[Caraviello]: Recommendation is that the engineering division be provided a suggested process to assist the city council in our October 2020 memo, as indicated by the process approved by the city council.

[Caraviello]: The petitioner would be required to draft a proposed licensing agreement in coordination with the legal department and engineering division.

[Caraviello]: The engineering division recommends that the city council determine if this process is adequate and reasonable pursuant to section 74-63 of Sydney Ordinance 2.

[Caraviello]: The engineering division recommends that existing encroachments be allowed to remain so situate for as long as they remain in good condition.

[Caraviello]: If they fall into disrepair or poor condition, the city will revoke the license.

[Caraviello]: The existing encroachments will include a metal fire escape, building cornices, and signs attached to the building three.

[Caraviello]: The easement plans indicates an easement area that extends beyond the existing projections into the public way.

[Caraviello]: The engineering division takes no exception to this approach.

[Caraviello]: However, the license agreement should indicate that no new encroachments or expansion of the existing encroachments is allowed beyond the limits of the existing encroachments as shown on the easement plan.

[Caraviello]: the license agreement should indicate that the licensee will maintain encroaching items in good condition.

[Caraviello]: Five, the license agreement should indicate that the city will revoke the license upon removal of the encroaching items.

[Caraviello]: Seven, the city council to decide

[Caraviello]: If the license agreement should include a renewal period or expiration.

[Caraviello]: Seven, city council should recommend a reasonable fee be charged by the city for use of the public property for the benefit of the petitioner.

[Caraviello]: Eight, the licensed area must include a level landing at the base of the ramp.

[Caraviello]: Nine, the license agreement should acknowledge that the potential presence of underground utilities beneath the proposed ramp should not restrict access to these utilities. 10,

[Caraviello]: The notification for the public hearing regarding this approval should include utility companies that have infrastructure in this block of Spring Street.

[Caraviello]: 11, sidewalk work associated ramp adjacent to the cracked sidewalk panels.

[Caraviello]: Adjacent cracked panels should be replaced.

[Caraviello]: 12, the ramp is a projection of the building and associated with the building exit entrance.

[Caraviello]: The ramp must be built per applicable building code inspected by the building department for code of compliance.

[Caraviello]: 13, the building indicates a national grid manhole near the proposed ramp.

[Caraviello]: The licensee agreement should not restrict access to this manhole.

[Caraviello]: 14, the plan indicates a tree pit on Spring Street that conflicts with the clearances needed for the ramp.

[Caraviello]: The new location appears reasonable and should be confirmed with the tree ward.

[Caraviello]: 15, the license agreement should indicate the minimum clearance between the minimum ramp and the front of the car to be 72 inches.

[Caraviello]: Call 781-393-2425 for further accommodations.

[Caraviello]: Communications, City Officers and Employees, 21449.

[Caraviello]: To President Richard Caraviello and member of the Medford City Council, registered voters.

[Caraviello]: The St.

[Caraviello]: Francis Parish Center

[Caraviello]: will no longer be available to the city as a polling location because the building has been sold.

[Caraviello]: I therefore have worked to identify a new polling location for Ward 2, Precinct 1.

[Caraviello]: I am recommending that you approve Roberts Elementary School as a new polling location for Ward 2, Precinct 1.

[Caraviello]: I've had a preliminary conversation with John McLaughlin of the Medford Public Schools, and he sees no obstacles to using the Roberts School for this purpose.

[Caraviello]: As you're aware, all municipal elections use the same ballots.

[Caraviello]: Placing 2-1 and 2-2 in the same location ensures that both polling locations would use the same ballots for state and federal elections as well.

[Caraviello]: Furthermore, there is a precedent in using schools as multiple polling locations.

[Caraviello]: The city already uses the former Columbus School, now renamed for both 5-1 and 5-2.

[Caraviello]: I need to notify the voters of a precinct change at least 20 days

[Caraviello]: in advance of the election.

[Caraviello]: I plan to make this notification via mailing required and by at least two reverse 911 calls for each election.

[Caraviello]: I will also place signs at the St.

[Caraviello]: Parish Center as required, notifying voters that the site is no longer a polling location.

[Caraviello]: In addition, we will make all the additional required notifications and we will place the new information on the city's website in advance of the two upcoming elections.

[Caraviello]: Once you have formally designated the new polling place, I will begin this notification process.

[Caraviello]: Our number one concern is to plan and execute full, fair, and transparent elections.

[Caraviello]: I am confident that this new polling location will allow us to achieve this goal for the voters of 2-1.

[Caraviello]: Thank you for your attention on this issue.

[Caraviello]: Please feel free to contact me if you have any concerns.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, would you like to address this?

[Caraviello]: Okay, any further discussion?

[Caraviello]: On the motion by Vice President Knight, seconded by?

[Caraviello]: Second.

[Caraviello]: Seconded by Councilor Bears.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, do we need a roll call on this?

[Caraviello]: Or is this a voice vote?

[Caraviello]: Let's call the roll on this to make sure everybody's in agreement.

[Caraviello]: Yes, I'm in affirmative, none in the negative.

[Caraviello]: Motion passes.

[Caraviello]: On the motion by Councilor Scarpelli, seconded by Vice President Knight, all in favor?

[Caraviello]: Aye.

[Caraviello]: Aye.

[Caraviello]: Motion passes.

[Caraviello]: 21437, dear Mr. President and Councilors, I respectfully request and recommend that the honorable body approve the following amendments to revise ordinance entitled Compensation Plans

[Caraviello]: Leave Ordinance Chapter 68, Personnel.

[Caraviello]: Amendment to the revised Ordinance Compensation Plan and Leave Ordinance Chapter 66, Personnel be it ordained by the Medford City Council of the City of Medford in Chapter 66 entitled Personnel Article 2 entitled Classification Compensation Plans Section 66-40 entitled Public Safety Personnel is hereby amended as follows.

[Caraviello]: Section 1.

[Caraviello]: In section 66.40, effective January 1, 2020, add 2% of the present amount of each step within the grades shown below to the said present amount of each step and adjust the sum thus obtained to the nearest and highest figure the following grades.

[Caraviello]: PS-2, Sergeant.

[Caraviello]: PS-3, Lieutenant.

[Caraviello]: PS-4, Captain.

[Caraviello]: PS-5, Chief.

[Caraviello]: Section two.

[Caraviello]: in section 66.40, effective January 1, 2021.

[Caraviello]: Add 2% of the present amount of each step within the grade shown below to the said present amount of each step and adjust the sum, thus obtain the nearest and highest figure for the following grades.

[Caraviello]: PS2, Sergeant, PS3, Lieutenant, PS4, Captain, PS5, Chief.

[Caraviello]: Section three, in section 66.40, effective January 1,

[Caraviello]: 2022 at 2% of the present amount of each step within the grade shown below to the set present amounts of each step and adjusted sum does obtain the nearest and highest figure the following grades.

[Caraviello]: PS2 Sergeant, PS3 Lieutenant, PS4 Captain, PS5 Chief.

[Caraviello]: This amendment is requested due to a recently negotiated agreement with the Medford Police Superior Officers Union that extended

[Caraviello]: the predecessor agreement to June 30, 2022.

[Caraviello]: It's estimated that the contract will cost approximately $307,656 in retroactive funds in fiscal year 2021.

[Caraviello]: There is available funding to cover this in the police department and the personnel budget.

[Caraviello]: 2-1-4-0-3, fiscal year 2022 budget submission.

[Caraviello]: Dear Mr. President, members of the City Council, pursuant to Mass General Law, Chapter 44, Section 32, I respectfully request and recommend that the City Council approve the fiscal year 2022 budget as submitted.

[Caraviello]: The total submitted appropriation for all departments, including schools, is $191 million, 642.

[Caraviello]: Account details are included with the budget presentation.

[Caraviello]: That number was off, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Oh, excuse me.

[Caraviello]: Is that the right number?

[Caraviello]: No, yeah.

[Caraviello]: Rather than have, I think that you'll have to call a different attorney every time.

[Caraviello]: That's something I can discuss that.

[Caraviello]: I can discuss that.

[Caraviello]: And if that would fall under the budget, that's already been created for KP law.

[Caraviello]: I don't know how my other Councilors feel about that, if they want to offer an opinion on that.

[Caraviello]: Well, one go-to person, and then that person could say, hey, call.

[Caraviello]: I'll refer you over to them.

[Caraviello]: But rather than just calling in a general person at a time, say, you know, attorney Smith is your contact, and you tell them your problem.

[Caraviello]: If they can't help you, they'll refer you to whatever person.

[Caraviello]: It's the same as you going to your GP doctor.

[Caraviello]: You know, they treat you for small stuff.

[Caraviello]: And they refer you out to whoever does whatever specialty you need.

[Caraviello]: That kind of defeats the whole purpose of what you're talking about.

[Caraviello]: I thought that we would have a direct contact rather than going through you.

[Caraviello]: Right.

[Caraviello]: That wasn't what I was thinking.

[Caraviello]: 2-1, 4-1-3 offered by Councilor Marks.

[Caraviello]: Be it resolved that the residential outside irrigation meter be discussed.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Marks.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Marks, if you could amend that for me, if the Water Commission could look into the program that the City of Revere uses.

[Caraviello]: They have, for their residents, not a big user, but they have a meter that goes onto the spigot, they charge them a nominal fee to rent for the season, and you put it on your outside spigot, and at the end of the season, you turn it in and you pay

[Caraviello]: for the water that you use for your outside water.

[Caraviello]: It doesn't cost any money for any plumbing or any of the, it doesn't cost $100 in plumbing fees to put it in.

[Caraviello]: And they see it seems to be working well, but say it's just a, it's a meter that goes onto your outside spigot.

[Caraviello]: And at the end of the season, you bring it back, you turn it back in and they charge you for whatever water you use through that.

[Caraviello]: It's a lot easier for the residents to use.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: You make it this.

[Caraviello]: I can't make it.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, for the neighbors who live down by the lakes, Pine Ridge, Oak Ridge, Sagamore, Pitcher, that whole area down there, every weekend,

[Caraviello]: they get inundated with cars.

[Caraviello]: I mean, not one or two cars, but hundreds of cars that it's barely passable for people to get by there.

[Caraviello]: And it's been going on for many years, but it seems over the last couple of years, it's gotten a lot worse than it has.

[Caraviello]: And it's not so much but the parking, but it's what's happening when people leave.

[Caraviello]: They're leaving trash in people's yards.

[Caraviello]: They're leaving trash all over the parkway.

[Caraviello]: you know, diapers and everything, it's not fair to these people.

[Caraviello]: And you know, it's not just the residents of that end, but it's also the residents that live up by the fells, on Governor's Ave every weekend, they're inundated with the cars and people from, you know, going into the fells with bikes and everything.

[Caraviello]: And you know, I guess that's the price we pay for having something, you know, as popular as the lake and the fells.

[Caraviello]: But going back down to the,

[Caraviello]: to the lakes and down that area.

[Caraviello]: The lower lake is not supposed to be for swimming or anything.

[Caraviello]: And I think at this point, we need to reach out to Representative Gobley.

[Caraviello]: to have the environmental police come down there on the weekends to start patrolling that area and make them knock and say, you wanna use the beach?

[Caraviello]: Go to the beach area.

[Caraviello]: But every year there's an accident up there.

[Caraviello]: If you go through the woods, it's littered with cans and toilet paper and diapers.

[Caraviello]: It's really a mess.

[Caraviello]: And I had the opportunity to drive down there at 5.30 on Monday morning.

[Caraviello]: The whole stretch of that Mystic Valley Parkway was just littered with cases of beer and bags of trash or anything.

[Caraviello]: It's really a shame.

[Caraviello]: But aside from that, we've had meetings down there with the residents, the mayor, the police, and I can't seem to come up with a solution.

[Caraviello]: Chief doesn't want to do anything.

[Caraviello]: They won't take it in tow because there's no signs posted.

[Caraviello]: and we don't have an ordinance to allow us to do that.

[Caraviello]: So after the last meeting we had last week, it was suggested that city council have the solicitor

[Caraviello]: draw up a language to amend the current private way parking ordinance they were having.

[Caraviello]: According to the Kim, it's not that big of a deal.

[Caraviello]: Two or three sentences get added on to that ordinance.

[Caraviello]: And if we can get it, hopefully get it out this week and get it back soon before the summer break, give these people that live in these neighborhoods some much needed help.

[Caraviello]: Like I say, because it's not fair to them every Saturday and Sunday that they had to, you know, you drive through the Winchester end

[Caraviello]: There's not a car parked on that over there.

[Caraviello]: And it's a shame that there's not more parking down that way.

[Caraviello]: The DCR has land to maybe put some more parking down there, and maybe they should do that at some point.

[Caraviello]: But like I said, it's just not fair that every week these residents have to suffer down there.

[Caraviello]: And I'm tired of going down there when I'm getting the calls and being a policeman for them.

[Caraviello]: So again, I ask my fellow councilors to support this.

[Caraviello]: I think there's some people here that may want to speak on that.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Karygiela.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Marks is right.

[Caraviello]: It's a cop-out because I've been down there with the police, and they're saying—I was there last Sunday with Officer Montgomery, and as fast as Councilor Paul knows, he's telling them not to pull on there, saying, you can park here all we want.

[Caraviello]: The biggest issue is there's no posted signs on there.

[Caraviello]: And but I agree with Council Marks, tow all the cars out of there, we'll deal with it later.

[Caraviello]: Because again, these are Medford residents' cars that you're towing.

[Caraviello]: They're all out of city and out of state plates there.

[Caraviello]: I was there, I'll tell you, last Sunday, in front of a neighbor's house, a pickup truck pulls up with six kayaks.

[Caraviello]: I says, well, what are you doing?

[Caraviello]: He says, I'm parking my truck here.

[Caraviello]: He says, it's a private property.

[Caraviello]: I says, well, I'm telling you, your car's not gonna be here when you come back.

[Caraviello]: Meanwhile, the tow trucks were there, the police were there, and Officer McGivery's standing there again.

[Caraviello]: I've been down there multiple Saturdays and Sundays with the police standing there, not able to do anything because we'll get the call from whoever's in charge that day, leave, nothing we can do, and run.

[Caraviello]: Tow the cars out of there.

[Caraviello]: If you see how fast, the people won't be back there the following week.

[Caraviello]: But one of the problems is it's not posted.

[Caraviello]: So we can't enforce anything that's not posted.

[Caraviello]: Towing companies said they'd be more than happy to give you all the signs you want to put up there.

[Caraviello]: But again, that's part of the ordinances.

[Caraviello]: It's going to be posted.

[Caraviello]: Get some signs up there quickly.

[Caraviello]: Help these people out now, not at the end of the summer when it's too late.

[Caraviello]: So.

[Caraviello]: We've been down there numerous times with the police, the traffic engineer, everybody.

[Caraviello]: Instead of offering solutions, they're offering excuses.

[Caraviello]: And that's really all it's done.

[Caraviello]: Again, they offered solutions about, we need to change this, we need to change things, but again.

[Caraviello]: Again, the traffic engineer was there, a representative from the police department was there.

[Caraviello]: Again, the tow company said they would give you all the signs you want to put up there, so when your car got towed, you'd know where they were going.

[Caraviello]: We're looking for immediate relief.

[Caraviello]: And listen, Councilor Morell is right.

[Caraviello]: I lived in the house there, and when the trucks came by, my house rattled.

[Caraviello]: And I don't know if anybody's gone by to see the island there.

[Caraviello]: Not that I'm opposed to having an island somewhere.

[Caraviello]: That is not a location where that island should be.

[Caraviello]: First of all, it's narrow for trucks to traverse at the time.

[Caraviello]: Route 60 is a major truck route.

[Caraviello]: Gasoline tankers go by there all day and night.

[Caraviello]: Be there at 2, 3 in the morning when those trucks go rolling down there in the dark.

[Caraviello]: They're not going to see that, and someone's going to hit it because there's no light there on either end.

[Caraviello]: Someone's going to hit it, and they're going to tip over, and you're going to see a fuel spill, similar to what we saw on the Merritt-Arlington line some years back.

[Caraviello]: They spilled 30,000 gallons of fuel into the Mystic River.

[Caraviello]: And I don't want to see that happen again over there.

[Caraviello]: So people are saying that I don't care about public safety.

[Caraviello]: The reason I have this here is because I do care about public safety.

[Caraviello]: And I care about the public safety of the people that live in that neighborhood.

[Caraviello]: That's my neighborhood where I live.

[Caraviello]: On Sunday, the island has been hit.

[Caraviello]: The 23rd regular meeting of the Medford City Council.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Seven in the affirmative.

[Caraviello]: Please rise and salute the flag.

[Caraviello]: Okay, pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, chapter 38, section 18, and the Governor's March 15th, 2020 order, imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Caraviello]: This meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: specific information, general guidelines for the remote participation by members of the public and the parties with the right of requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medford.org.

[Caraviello]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Caraviello]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be made, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the meetings in real time by a technological means.

[Caraviello]: In the event we're able to do so, despite past evidence, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of the proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order, imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted by a remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: specific information and general guidance for remote participation by members of the public and the parties with the right of requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medford.org.

[Caraviello]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained therein.

[Caraviello]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Caraviello]: In the event we're able to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive recording

[Caraviello]: of the proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: Hearings, 21362 City of Medford, notice of a public hearing.

[Caraviello]: A public hearing will be held by the Medford City Council.

[Caraviello]: in Howard F. Alden Memorial Auditorium, 85 George P. Hazard Drive, Medford, Mass., on Tuesday evening, June 1st, 2021, at 7 o'clock p.m., on a petition from Herbert G. Chambers of Herb Chambers BMW of Medford at 60 Mystic Avenue, Medford, for Class II used auto sales, use special permit Class IV, auto repair use permit, in accordance with Chapter 94 Zoning Ordinance of the City of Medford, Section 94-1.

[Caraviello]: 148D, table of use regulations, automotive uses 27A, for permission to operate its class two secondhand motor vehicle sales and automobile uses 37, for permission to operate its automotive repair establishment at 60 Mr. Gary Method, a commercial two C2 zoning district.

[Caraviello]: Communications from the Mayor.

[Caraviello]: 287, May 26th, 2021.

[Caraviello]: Dear Mr. President, City Councilors, I respectfully request to recommend that your own body approve the following loan order.

[Caraviello]: City of Edmonton loan order, water bonds.

[Caraviello]: Be it ordered that $1,222,000 is appropriate for the purpose of making improvements to the city's water system, including constructing and reconstructing water mains and other costs incidentally related there to meet this appropriation.

[Caraviello]: with the approval of the mayor has authorized to borrow a set amount pursuant to Chapter 44, Section 8, Number 5 of the Mass General Laws, or pursuant to any other enabling authority, and to issue bonds or notes of the city thereafter that the treasurer, with the approval of the mayor, is authorized to borrow all or a portion of such amount from the Massachusetts Water Authority pursuant to MWRA's Local Water Systems Assistance Program, and in connection therewith

[Caraviello]: to enter into a loan agreement and or financial assistance agreement with the MWRA, and to accept any grants for the project from the MWRA, provided that the amount of the authorized borrowing shall be reduced by the amount of any such grants received from the MWRA.

[Caraviello]: And furthermore, that any premium received by the city upon the sale of any bonds or notes approved by this order, lest any such premium applied to the payment of costs of issuance of such bonds or notes,

[Caraviello]: may be applied to the payment of costs approved by this audit in accordance with Chapter 44, Section 20 of the General Laws, thereby reducing the amount authorized to be borrowed to pay such costs by a like amount.

[Caraviello]: And be it further resolved that the treasurer is authorized to file an application with the appropriate official of the Commonwealth of Mass to qualify under Chapter 44A of the General Laws, any and all bonds that the city is authorized to

[Caraviello]: to be borrowed pursuant to this loan order and provide such information and execute such documents as such officials of the Commonwealth may require in connection therewith.

[Caraviello]: Very truly yours, Mayor Brianna Longo-Grant.

[Caraviello]: 21st regular meeting of the Medford City Council, May 25th, 2021.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order, imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: Specific information in the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and private parties with the right or requirement to attend this meeting can be found at

[Caraviello]: the City of Medford website at www.medford.org.

[Caraviello]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen, watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Caraviello]: No in-person attendance of members will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Caraviello]: In the event that we're able to do so despite our best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or the Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording transcript or the comprehensive record of the proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: Legal notice 21370 petition for a grant of location, national grid, not the end of the Massachusetts.

[Caraviello]: Location of underground electric conduits, Medford, Massachusetts city clerk's office.

[Caraviello]: You were hereby notified by all of Medford city council

[Caraviello]: that the Medford City Council will hold a public hearing via Zoom on Tuesday, March 25th, May 25th, a link to be posted no later than Friday, May 21st, on a petition of Massachusetts Electrical Company doing business as that's good for permission to construct a lone underground electric conduit, including the necessary sustaining and protecting fixtures under and across the public ways

[Caraviello]: here named said underground electric car to be located substantially in accordance with the plan marked Boston Avenue Metro Mass and filed in the office of the city clerk.

[Caraviello]: Wherefore, it prays that after due notice and hearing, as provided by law, it be granted the location permission to excavate the public highways and run and maintain underground electric conduits together with such sustained protective fixtures as it may find necessary for the transmission of electricity, said underground conduits to be located substantially enclosed with the planned files here with Mark Boston Avenue, Miffin Mass, and available for inspection.

[Caraviello]: in the office of the City Clerk, Method City Hall, room 105, 85 George P. Hatcher Drive, Method Mass 02155.

[Caraviello]: The following are the streets and highways referred to.

[Caraviello]: Plan number 30278888, Boston Avenue.

[Caraviello]: National grid to install, beginning at the point of approximately 200 feet northwest of the center line of the intersection of Boston Avenue and College Avenue, and continue approximately 65 feet in the northeast direction and install

[Caraviello]: two to three inch secondary duct from the existing pole number 3310-5, 65 feet north east towards 468 Boston Avenue and MBTI.

[Caraviello]: Location approximately as shown on a plan filed in the office of the city clerk, approved by the chief engineer with the following conditions.

[Caraviello]: The engineering division recommends that this grant of location be approved with the following conditions.

[Caraviello]: One, the granting location is limited to 65 feet of duct bank as described in the GOL document as follows.

[Caraviello]: National grid to install beginning at a point approximately 200 feet northwest of the central line of the intersection of Boston Avenue and College Ave and continuing approximately 65 feet in the northeast direction.

[Caraviello]: Install two or three feet of secondary duct from existing pole

[Caraviello]: 3310-5, 65 feet northeast toward 468 Boston Ave, MBTA Yard.

[Caraviello]: Before starting work, the contractor.

[Caraviello]: shall notify DIGSAFE and shall obtain all applicable permits from the engineering division.

[Caraviello]: The project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[Caraviello]: Three, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other apparatuses are adversely impacted.

[Caraviello]: National Grid should ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[Caraviello]: Number four,

[Caraviello]: The plan included with the petition does not include existing utilities.

[Caraviello]: The street opening permit application must include an engineered plan showing existing utilities.

[Caraviello]: The street opening permit application must also include a copy of the MWRA 8M permit.

[Caraviello]: Number five.

[Caraviello]: Roadway service restoration must be coordinated with the Green Line Extension project.

[Caraviello]: At a minimum, final service restoration normally offsets, offset limits your line and abut final service restoration resulting from Green Line Extension utility work.

[Caraviello]: If possible, final restoration should be coordinated to minimize seams.

[Caraviello]: The southerly offset must be also coordinated with the Greenline Extension Project and be a minimum of 10 feet.

[Caraviello]: The final restoration plan must be approved by the engineering division.

[Caraviello]: Number six, sidewalk surface restoration must be coordinated with the Greenline Extension Project.

[Caraviello]: At a minimum, final sidewalk restoration on the eastern side of Boston Avenue should include new cement concrete and vertical granite curbing.

[Caraviello]: The existing concrete barrier should not be replaced.

[Caraviello]: The final restoration plan must be approved by the engineering division.

[Caraviello]: Number seven, pavement markings must be restored.

[Caraviello]: Temporary markings must be painted during the interim period between trench patch and final restoration.

[Caraviello]: Number eight, the project site must be swept daily and shall be kept free of debris for the duration of the installation.

[Caraviello]: Approved by the superintendent of wires.

[Caraviello]: Okay, plans can be viewed in the city clerk's office, 781-393-2425.

[Caraviello]: Do we have somebody from National Grant on the call here?

[Caraviello]: Okay, and this is a hearing for a grant to location.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: I'm sorry, can we get your last name again?

[Caraviello]: Sure, Socrates Perez.

[Caraviello]: Okay, so Ms.

[Caraviello]: Socrates, with this public hearing, are you in favor of this project?

[Caraviello]: Yes, I am.

[Caraviello]: Is there anyone else in favor of this project?

[Caraviello]: Hearing and seeing none, we close this portion of the hearing.

[Caraviello]: Is there anyone here in opposition to this project?

[Caraviello]: Hearing and seeing none, we close this section of

[Caraviello]: the hearing.

[Caraviello]: So, Mr. Socrates, if you can give us a brief description of what's going on in this project.

[Caraviello]: Okay, do anyone have any questions for National Grid?

[Caraviello]: Councilor Rao.

[Caraviello]: Got it.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Tim.

[Caraviello]: Now, any further discussion?

[Caraviello]: So on the motion by Vice President Knight, seconded by Councilor Scarpelli.

[Caraviello]: For approval, Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: President Caraviello?

[Caraviello]: Yes, I move the affirmative.

[Caraviello]: Motion passes.

[Caraviello]: Legal notice 21371, petition for grant of location, National Grid, North Andover, Massachusetts.

[Caraviello]: Location of underground conduits, Medford, Massachusetts City Clerk's Office.

[Caraviello]: You are hereby notified that by order of the Medford City Council, the Medford City Council will hold a public hearing via Zoom on Tuesday, May 25th, 2021.

[Caraviello]: The link can be posted no later than Friday, May 21st, 2021, on a petition of Massachusetts Electric Company doing business as national grid, with permission to construct a loan of underground electric conduits, including the necessary sustaining and protecting fixtures under and across the public way or ways hereafter named.

[Caraviello]: Said underground electric conduits to be located

[Caraviello]: substantially in accordance with the plan marked Boston Avenue, Mifflin Mass, filed with the Office of City Clerk.

[Caraviello]: Wherefore, it prays that after due notice and hearing as provided by law, it will be granted a location for permission to excavate the public highways and run and maintain underground electric conduits together with such sustaining and protecting fixtures as it may find necessary for the transmission of electricity

[Caraviello]: said underground conduits to be located substantially in accordance with the plan filed here in Marks.

[Caraviello]: Boston Avenue, Medford, Massachusetts has been available for inspection in the office of the city clerk, Medford City Hall, room 103, 85 George P. Hadson Drive, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155.

[Caraviello]: On the motion by Vice President Knight to have a brief synopsis by the city engineer, Mr. Tim McGiven.

[Caraviello]: I'm sorry.

[Caraviello]: And it's nearing completion.

[Caraviello]: You've got those four blocks, the trucks are there.

[Caraviello]: pave those probably maybe a hundred yards of paving to at least make that section look uniform.

[Caraviello]: I mean, I think it's harder for them to cut off sections of concrete and put in little patches and it'd be more uniform if it's just paved with those four blocks.

[Caraviello]: And further, I don't know if anyone's also driven by there,

[Caraviello]: They put an island there on the top of right under this intersection of Woburn Street and high.

[Caraviello]: And I don't know if our traffic engineer signed off on that.

[Caraviello]: It's in a very dangerous location.

[Caraviello]: There's no light on it.

[Caraviello]: And anybody coming up during the night is not going to see it.

[Caraviello]: I'm telling you now, that's going to be hit multiple times going forward.

[Caraviello]: The science team coming down and

[Caraviello]: give them a quota on paving on paving that from the whole four block section and having that our traffic engineer review that islands in the interest of public safety Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Second by Councilor Scarpelli, Mr. Quinn, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 18, 2020 order imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: Specific information and guidelines for all participation by members of the public and or parties with a right or requirement

[Caraviello]: to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medford.org.

[Caraviello]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Caraviello]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technology means.

[Caraviello]: In the event we were able to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio, video, recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of the meeting as soon as possible.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: So with the Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, chapter 30, section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order, imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: Specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with a right or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medford.org.

[Caraviello]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link therein.

[Caraviello]: In the event we were able to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of the proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Caraviello]: This amount is being requested to subsidize the fiscal 2022 Water and Sewer Enterprise Fund budget due to the health and pandemic, health pandemic and current economic conditions.

[Caraviello]: Retained earnings are reserves of the Water and Sewer Fund.

[Caraviello]: Reserves can be used for any lawful purpose, which serve primarily to provide financial security in cases of unforeseen events, such as COVID-19 or capital replacement.

[Caraviello]: Hearings.

[Caraviello]: 2145, legal notice, City of Medford.

[Caraviello]: CBBG annual action plan, public hearing, and 30 day public comment period.

[Caraviello]: A virtual public hearing will be held by the Medford City Council on Tuesday, May 4th, 2021 via remote video conferencing.

[Caraviello]: Conferencing details will be posted on the city clerk's office prior to the hearing.

[Caraviello]: The purpose of the public hearing will be to invite the general public and representative of public service agencies to express comments regarding the city's annual action plan for community development and planning.

[Caraviello]: The action plan contains proposed use

[Caraviello]: community development block grant funds for the program year, which extends from July 1st, 2021 through June 30th, 2022.

[Caraviello]: The office of community development will be requesting that the city, that the Medford city council authorize Mayor Brian McLaren, official representative of the city of Medford to submit the annual action plan application for funds and all other assurances and certifications to the U.S.

[Caraviello]: departments of housing and urban development.

[Caraviello]: The city is applying

[Caraviello]: or $1,546,980 block grant funds.

[Caraviello]: Beginning April 12th, 2020, the annual draft action plan will be available for review and comment and can be obtained by contacting the Office of Community Development at 781-393-2480 or OCD at MedfordMethod.gov.

[Caraviello]: written comments must be submitted no later than May 12th, 2021 to Ashley Williams, City Hall 85, George P. Hesse Drive, room 308, FMS 0255, or abwilliams at medfordmass.gov.

[Caraviello]: Okay, do we have a, where this is a public hearing, do we have anyone here speaking in favor of this?

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, if I may.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Is there anyone else in favor of this petition?

[Caraviello]: Hearing and seeing none, we close this portion of the hearing.

[Caraviello]: Is there anyone here that is in opposition to this plan?

[Caraviello]: Hearing and seeing none, we close that part of the meeting.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, Vice President Knight.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: And I have received several calls from people that have used that office and we're happy with the results of that office.

[Caraviello]: So I do support the additional funding if it is available.

[Caraviello]: Vice Councilor Marks.

[Caraviello]: Alicia?

[Caraviello]: I do not have, Alicia, do we have an indication of what the dollar amount will be?

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: We will close that part of the meeting in opposition.

[Caraviello]: Do we have a motion on the floor to accept the plan?

[Caraviello]: I think Mr. President, it's a 30 day public comment period.

[Caraviello]: Yes, yes.

[Caraviello]: When we vote on this, it will be put in the paper for the 30 day commentary.

[Caraviello]: I have told residents to call.

[Caraviello]: Once you call me, get asked them to call your office and the mayor's office.

[Caraviello]: Okay, any further questions?

[Caraviello]: On the motion by Councilor Marks for approval, seconded by Vice President Knight.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Six in the affirmative, one absent.

[Caraviello]: Whereas the voice of our city's youth has been restricted throughout COVID-19 pandemic end, whereas the youth in the city of Bedford represent not only our future, but our present ends, whereas our youth

[Caraviello]: deserve every opportunity to flourish and be provided with the resources and services necessary to meet the challenges and problems they face.

[Caraviello]: Be it so ordered that the Medford City Council adopt the provisions of Massachusetts General Law, Chapter 40, Section 80, enabling the establishment of a youth commission for the purpose of carrying out the programs which may be designed or established to meet the opportunities, challenges, and problems of youth in the city of Medford, and be it resolved

[Caraviello]: The Medford City Council requests that the city solicitor provide to Medford City Council with a draft ordinance.

[Caraviello]: The language of section 8E can be found below for the following reference purposes.

[Caraviello]: Section 8E, a city- Mr. President, you don't have to get into that.

[Caraviello]: I'll read it.

[Caraviello]: A city or town which accepts this section may establish a youth commission, herein I recall the commission, the purpose of carrying out programs which may be designed to establish, meet the opportunities, challenges, and problems of youth

[Caraviello]: of said city, town in conjunction with any similar or related programs of any agency of the Commonwealth or any agency of the federal government.

[Caraviello]: It shall keep back your records of its meetings and actions.

[Caraviello]: It shall file a name report, which shall be printed in the case of the towns in the annual town report.

[Caraviello]: Commission may appoint such clerks and other employees as they may from time to time require.

[Caraviello]: Commission shall consist of not less than three

[Caraviello]: No more than 21 members in cities with cities.

[Caraviello]: The members shall be appointed by the mayor subject to the provision of the city charter.

[Caraviello]: Some of the cities that having or operating on the plan D or provision of the city charter.

[Caraviello]: Such appointments shall be made by citizens subject to the provisional charter and the towns.

[Caraviello]: They should be appointed by the selection, accepting towns, having a manager or form of government.

[Caraviello]: Which towns appointments shall be made by the town manager subject to the approval of the selection.

[Caraviello]: Commission is first established, the terms of the members shall be for one, two, or three years, so arranged that the terms of approximately one-third of the members will expire each year, and their successors shall be appointed for a term of three years each.

[Caraviello]: Any member of the commission so appointed may, after public meeting if requested, be removed for cause by the vacancy occurring otherwise by the expiration of a term, and the city or town shall be filled for the unexpired term

[Caraviello]: in the same manner as the original appointment.

[Caraviello]: Said commission may receive gifts of property, both real and personal, in the name of the city and town, subject to the approval of the city council, and the city council, where the selectmen in the town, such gifts managed and controlled by the commission for purposes of this selection.

[Caraviello]: Pursuing the Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, chapter 38, section 18, and the Governor's March 15th, 2020 order, imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in place.

[Caraviello]: This meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: Specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right of requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medford.org.

[Caraviello]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to

[Caraviello]: listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained here and no in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Caraviello]: In the event we were able to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community's website, an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of the proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.
