[Caraviello]: I mean, the affirmative motion passes.

[Caraviello]: Communications from the mayor.

[Caraviello]: Yeah, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: I hereby propose the following amendment to the revised ordinances of the city of Bedford.

[Caraviello]: Section 94-35A of the revised ordinance of the city of Bedford, Massachusetts is hereby amended to read as follows.

[Caraviello]: A, a board of appeals provided under Mass General Law chapter 48 section 12 is hereby established consisting of five members who shall be appointed by the mayor.

[Caraviello]: The members shall serve a term of three years.

[Caraviello]: The members shall be residents of the city.

[Caraviello]: The board shall annually elect a chairman among its own members and a clerk.

[Caraviello]: The mayor shall also annually appoint two associate members

[Caraviello]: of such Board of Appeals who shall each be appointed for a one-year term and who shall sit on the Board upon the designation of the Chairman to act in the event of a vacancy, or the absence or inability to act, or an interest on the part of a member thereof.

[Caraviello]: Members and the associate members shall serve until a successor is appointed and qualified, unless sooner removed.

[Caraviello]: Submitted by Her Honor the Mayor, Brianna Lundgren.

[Caraviello]: 10th regular meeting of the Medford City Council, March 9th, 2021.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Bears.

[Caraviello]: Present.

[Caraviello]: Present.

[Caraviello]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020, order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 30, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020, order imposing the strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted by remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: Specific information and general guidelines

[Caraviello]: I have an announcement to make that the Council Chambers are now open to the public.

[Caraviello]: We do have some guests here this evening.

[Caraviello]: We have taken all the necessary guidelines given to us by the Board of Health.

[Caraviello]: Currently, we have a capacity of 18 seats.

[Caraviello]: They're all spaced six feet apart.

[Caraviello]: The first row, instead of being six feet from the rail, is 10 feet from the rail to give a little extra buffer to make sure that everybody is safely distanced from each other.

[Caraviello]: There are signs on the building outside, so everybody will adhere to the proper protocol.

[Caraviello]: The messenger is logging everybody that comes into the meeting, and he will give it to the clerk so they can put it in to the computer on the next day.

[Caraviello]: So anyone who wishes to come to meetings going forward, the chamber is open for public participation or anything you want to say here.

[Caraviello]: So before we start the meeting, we have Marianne O'Connor, who's going to give us a little brief synopsis on where we are with vaccinations and general health things.

[Caraviello]: Marianne, are you here?

[Caraviello]: Good evening, Council President members City Council overview of what you've been doing and where we're going with the COVID in the vaccination process.

[Caraviello]: The ninth regular meeting of the Medford City Council.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Yes, this is the president.

[Caraviello]: Chapter 38, section 18 of the governor's March 15th order, imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: Specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with a right or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at

[Caraviello]: www.medford.org.

[Caraviello]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained here.

[Caraviello]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Caraviello]: In the event we were able to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford

[Caraviello]: community media website and audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of the proceedings as soon as possible.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Knight, would you please take the chair?

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Today I received a call

[Caraviello]: couple of residents that the bins are overflowing again.

[Caraviello]: And this is the second time that I've reached out to the company to have that emptied.

[Caraviello]: So they were emptied, I think, later this evening.

[Caraviello]: When I reached out to the company that owns that, Standard Recycling, those were supposed to have been removed last week because they weren't in compliance with our current ordinance.

[Caraviello]: When I talked to the gentleman again today, he said he promised they'll be up by the end of the week.

[Caraviello]: But, Mr. President, this is already twice that I've had to reach out to them.

[Caraviello]: They're not showing the good faith that, I mean, even in the beginning, I mean, these are getting filled.

[Caraviello]: So I think it's time that we reach out to Kimco, we sign an agreement with this company for the placements of those containers on their property, and have them appear before the council, and so the neighbors can make this pleasure known.

[Caraviello]: about those being there because they're a site hazard and they're just a hazard in general.

[Caraviello]: So I would ask that if the administration contact Kimco and request that they come to the council within the next 14 days.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Councilor Lonnox.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Vice President.

[Caraviello]: Many of us remember Mr. Wells, a longtime football coach.

[Caraviello]: For me personally, the Wells family, they were an extension of the Caraviello family.

[Caraviello]: Very close with my family.

[Caraviello]: And so I knew him a little different than anyone else here, but good family.

[Caraviello]: Again, always took care of the kids on the football team, good community man.

[Caraviello]: To the younger members who don't remember, in the early 70s and late 60s, when the Bruins were the Big Bad Bruins, Mr. Wells worked the door at the Boston Garden.

[Caraviello]: And he was very generous to us.

[Caraviello]: We would go to the Boston Garden,

[Caraviello]: give us the nod and then he'd let us go to the gate and watch the game.

[Caraviello]: So again, he was, all the kids, everybody that went there.

[Caraviello]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council, that the city administration plan an update on the status of 8086 Nail Street, which had a severe fire last year and was left open to the elements for several months, and how the administration plans to address health and safety code enforcement

[Caraviello]: to ensure safety for any new construction in our neighboring residential building.

[Caraviello]: Be it further resolved that this item reappear on the city council agenda in two weeks for an update in discussion or further action that can be taken by the council to address this issue.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Bears, before I think I had the opportunity to speak with building commissioner Moki today, and this is private property and is not germane to the city council.

[Caraviello]: According to him, the building is closed to their satisfaction, and the person who owns the property has not filed for any building permits or any new construction.

[Caraviello]: So unfortunately at this time, after my conversation with the building commissioner, I am going to rule this out of order, Councilor Bearss.

[Caraviello]: Because it's a private property, and we have no jurisdiction on that.

[Caraviello]: And there is no building permit that has been filed.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Private property and we have no jurisdiction over private property.

[Caraviello]: going through a war zone, I think South Street is pretty much done too.

[Caraviello]: The eighth regular meeting of the Medford City Council, February 23rd, 2021.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Present.

[Caraviello]: Please rise and exclude the plaque.

[Caraviello]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order,

[Caraviello]: of the open meeting law, ADA section 18 and the governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Caraviello]: This meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members and of the public and parties with the right or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website

[Caraviello]: at www.medford.org.

[Caraviello]: For accessing for this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Caraviello]: No in-person attendance of the members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time.

[Caraviello]: via technological means.

[Caraviello]: In the event we were able to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or the Medford community website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Caraviello]: OK, before we start, I have a letter to read it to the record from the Massachusetts Office of the Attorney General.

[Caraviello]: On or about June 25, 2020, a complaint was filed by Linda Julian with the Medford City Council alleging a violation of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 38, Section 18-25, General Law, Chapter 38, Section 23B, 940,

[Caraviello]: Our office received the response from the council on July 14th, 2020.

[Caraviello]: After 30 days have passed since the complaint was filed with the public body, but within 90 days from the date of the alleged violation, a complaint may be filed with the division of open government for review, general law 30A section 23B 940-29056.

[Caraviello]: We sent you an email on July 27th,

[Caraviello]: 2020 saying that if we did not receive the original complaint and a request from you by September 18, 2020, we would presume the action taken by the council was sufficient and would close this file.

[Caraviello]: Our office currently has no record of a request for further review from you in this matter.

[Caraviello]: Therefore, we now consider this matter closed.

[Caraviello]: Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions or if you believe anything stated in this letter to be accurate.

[Caraviello]: Erica Warren, Massachusetts Office of the Attorney General.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, if you could please read that into the records.

[Caraviello]: Put it into the records.

[Caraviello]: 21-076 offered by Councilor Falco and President Caraviello being resolved that the city administration develop a pilot program to resurface a portion of our roads using recycled asphalt.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Falco.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Councilor Falco.

[Caraviello]: I want to thank Councilor Falco again for bringing this forward.

[Caraviello]: This is something Councilor Falco and I brought up last year also.

[Caraviello]: And again, the benefit of using our own recycled alcohol is normally, I don't know if anybody, but normally when they mill a street, they take it to a plant and they give it to them.

[Caraviello]: We have to buy it back from them.

[Caraviello]: So what these companies do is they do it right on site.

[Caraviello]: So as they're milling and grinding, they're making the asphalt right behind the truck, and it's coming right back out.

[Caraviello]: So again, it was something that we brought up last year.

[Caraviello]: It didn't really go anywhere.

[Caraviello]: And I would hope that the administration and Mr. Cameron's look at this again, especially when money's tight, then money for roads.

[Caraviello]: And if we can do two roads for the price of one, I say that's what we need to do.

[Caraviello]: It's time that this be looked at.

[Caraviello]: And again, I hope that this gets looked at again this year.

[Caraviello]: So I thank you, Councilor Falco and myself for bringing this up.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Any further discussion?

[Caraviello]: Is it present?

[Caraviello]: Councilor Marks, if you can recall, Councilor Falco and myself also brought out a program for a company to come to the city that does that.

[Caraviello]: They go out there and set your sidewalks.

[Caraviello]: and they tell you which ones they can easily fix by either grinding or bringing them down to level.

[Caraviello]: So again, this is something that's been brought up to the administration before.

[Caraviello]: And if you do a little bit of work, this company's all here to do that stuff.

[Caraviello]: So again, there's no reason why we can't be looking into it, especially during these tough financial times.

[Caraviello]: Okay, the motion by Councilor Falco, seconded by Councilor Marks.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Assembly affirmative.

[Caraviello]: He has spoken with the building commissioner, Moki.

[Caraviello]: And on Saturday, he told us where he said, I'll have a truck out there on Saturday.

[Caraviello]: did have a truck out there on Saturday to empty the bins.

[Caraviello]: And he told me that he will be having a truck there this week to take the collection bins out of there until he conforms to the new ordinance.

[Caraviello]: And on another note, he also stated that he signed the lease with Kimco to rent that spot.

[Caraviello]: And I explained to him that he should maybe

[Caraviello]: Wait till he goes a little further to see where the council wants to go with that collection box.

[Caraviello]: So just a little update.

[Caraviello]: The seventh regular meeting of the Medford City Council, February 16th, 2021.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: His hand is up.

[Caraviello]: His hand is up.

[Caraviello]: He's present.

[Caraviello]: OK, great.

[Caraviello]: Present.

[Caraviello]: President, please rise and salute the flag.

[Caraviello]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law,

[Caraviello]: Chapter 38, section 18 of the governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Caraviello]: This meeting of the City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: Specific information and guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and their parties with the right or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medford.org.

[Caraviello]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Caraviello]: No in-person attendance of the members of the public will be permitted, but every method will be made to ensure that the public can adequately

[Caraviello]: access to proceedings in real time by a technological means.

[Caraviello]: In the event we're able to do so despite our best efforts, we will post in the city of Medford or the community media website in audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of the proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: Hearings 21058.

[Caraviello]: Petition for a grant of location, Verizon New England Inc, underground cables and fixtures, Medford Mass.

[Caraviello]: You are hereby notified that the, by the order of the Medford City Council, public hearing be given via Zoom at seven o'clock on Tuesday, February 16th, 2020 on a petition of Verizon New England for permission to locate underground cables and fixtures, including the necessary sustaining and protecting figures to be owned and used in common by petitioners along and across the following public way, Medford Street,

[Caraviello]: Also for permission to erect and maintain poles, wires, and cables together with anchors, guides, and other such sustaining and protecting fixtures that they find necessary said poles to be erected substantially in accordance with plan marks VZNE Inc.

[Caraviello]: Plan Number 1A4Y6XY, dated December 30th, 2020, and filed in the office of the city clerk

[Caraviello]: Whereas it prays that after due notice and hearings by law, it will be granted joint or identical locations for permission to erect and maintain poles, wires, and cables together with anchors, guides, and other such sustaining and protecting fixtures as they find necessary.

[Caraviello]: said polls to be erected and substantially in accordance with the plan marked VZNE Inc.

[Caraviello]: Plan Number 1A4Y6XY and available for inspection in the Office of City Clerk, Medford City Hall, Room 103.

[Caraviello]: George P. has to drive.

[Caraviello]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, 38 section 18 of the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medford.org.

[Caraviello]: To attend this meeting, excuse me.

[Caraviello]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Caraviello]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceeding in real time via technological means.

[Caraviello]: In the event that we're able to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford community website

[Caraviello]: in audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: Motions, orders, and resolutions.

[Caraviello]: 19660, an ordinance amending Chapter 20 of the Ordinance of the City of Medford.

[Caraviello]: Promote, prevent, support behavioral health commissions.

[Caraviello]: Be it ordained by the City Council of the City of Medford that Chapter 20 of the Ordinance of the City of Medford, as most recently amended, is hereby further amended by inserting after the present article, and following article, Promote, Prevent, Support, Behavioral Health Commission.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Marks.

[Caraviello]: Yeah.

[Caraviello]: So which one was the purpose section?

[Caraviello]: We're waving in the ring, okay, I'll vote you by council mark second by vice-president night to waive the readings.

[Caraviello]: 7 in the affirmative, motion passes.

[Caraviello]: The purpose of this particular resolution is to monitor, track and inform and make recommendations to city officials and policy makers in the city of Medford about behavioral health data issues, needs and efforts within the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: Build community partnerships and collaborations amongst providers, social service organizations, and city government to identify and address the social determinants of health, social, environmental, and economic challenges that contribute to poor behavioral, mental health, and substance

[Caraviello]: use outcomes.

[Caraviello]: Serve as an advisory body to the city on all matters dealing with behavioral health and make recommendations to address the needs such as evidence-based practices, programs, and systems.

[Caraviello]: Environmental or policy changes to prevent behavioral health disorders and promote behavioral health and wellness.

[Caraviello]: Set overall community-wide goals and create a strategic plan for achieving mental and emotional well-being for all residents of Medford.

[Caraviello]: be the clearinghouse and repository for behavioral health program and plans within the city to ensure efforts are purposeful and aligned with the overall strategic plans and goals.

[Caraviello]: Behavioral health is a state of mental, emotional, being, and or choices and actions that affect wellness, substance abuse,

[Caraviello]: in misuse of one set of behavioral health problems.

[Caraviello]: Others include, but not limited to, serious psychological distress, suicide, and mental illness.

[Caraviello]: Specific goals may be approved by the commission as it seeks to fulfill its promise.

[Caraviello]: This paper here is going on its first reading this evening.

[Caraviello]: Do we have any questions?

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[Caraviello]: Diane Sullivan, name and address of the record, please.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Diane.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Councilor Monk.

[Caraviello]: Any further questions?

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Falco.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Councilor Bears.

[Caraviello]: Any further questions?

[Caraviello]: All in the motion by Vice President Knight, seconded by Councilor Falco.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll for this paper to take its first reading.

[Caraviello]: Yes, seven in the affirmative, motion passes.

[Caraviello]: 20295, another paper taking its first reading this evening.

[Caraviello]: This was for the unattended donation collection bin ordinance.

[Caraviello]: The purpose of this was to regulate the placement of unattended donation bins within the city.

[Caraviello]: On the motion by Councilor Marks, seconded by Vice President Knight, Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: President Caraviello?

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: 7 in the affirmative, motion passes.

[Caraviello]: And the purpose of this is to regulate the placements of unattended donation bins within the city as to promote the community's health, safety and welfare by regulating unattended donation collection bins for clothing and other salvageable personal property in the city.

[Caraviello]: Ensure that unattended donation collections bins do not pose a hazard to a pedestrian and vehicular traffic.

[Caraviello]: to ensure that the material is not allowed to accumulate outside the unattended donation collection bins, where it may be scattered by weather, animals, and humans, and establish a criteria to ensure that the unattended donation collection bins are suitably located and maintained in a clean and safe condition.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: On the motion by Vice President Knight.

[Caraviello]: Second.

[Caraviello]: Seconded by Councilor Scarpelli.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Any council remarks?

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: And if I could put my two cents in on this.

[Caraviello]: You know, the reason I sponsored this a couple years ago was because there was a bin, stuff, you know, screwing all over the place, and I ended up calling the company who had it, and the gentleman who I spoke to, which was very nice,

[Caraviello]: He said he came right down and cleaned it, but he asked me if we had any ordinances in our city about this.

[Caraviello]: I said no, we hadn't, and he was surprised that we hadn't.

[Caraviello]: And he explained to me that many of the cities have the ordinances, and they also pay permit fees.

[Caraviello]: And that's what spurred me to do this again, and I'm glad we finally passed this after many years.

[Caraviello]: I'm glad we're moving forward.

[Caraviello]: So on the motion by Vice President Knight, seconded by Councilor Scarpelli.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Seven in the affirmative, motion passes.

[Caraviello]: And this was also for the take its first reading.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: 21054 offered by Councilor Falco being resolved that the City Council be provided an update from the administration as to the home rule petition approved by the City Council September regarding a Charter Commission.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Falco?

[Caraviello]: On the motion by Councilor Falco, seconded by Councilor Knight.

[Caraviello]: Any further discussion?

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk.

[Caraviello]: Okay, Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: 21057 offered by Councilor Morell and Councilor Bears, whereas commercial grade gas leaf blowers directly emit air pollutants, including carbon monoxide, which contributes to ground level ozone, nitrous oxides, which contribute to smog formation, hydrocarbons, which can be carcinogenic in nitrous oxides, and whereas commercial grade gas leaf blowers can operate at high decibels,

[Caraviello]: levels harmful to hearing and health of users and nearby residents, and whereas commercial-grade gas leaf blowers launch particulates and potentially hazardous materials into the air at a rate of over 150 miles per hour.

[Caraviello]: Now, therefore, be it so resolved that the city council request that the city solicitor draft language to establish an ordinance around commercial-grade leaf blower use within the city

[Caraviello]: in the interest of public safety for Medford residents.

[Caraviello]: The fifth regular meeting of the Medford City Council, February 2nd, 2021.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Present.

[Caraviello]: Assembly affirmative.

[Caraviello]: Please rise and salute the flag.

[Caraviello]: I pledge allegiance to the flag

[Caraviello]: of the United States of America, and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation, under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

[Caraviello]: All right.

[Caraviello]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 30A, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing the strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: Specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and your parties with the right

[Caraviello]: and or requirements to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordmass.org.

[Caraviello]: With this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Caraviello]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Caraviello]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Method community media website, an audio or video recording transcript, a rather comprehensive record of the proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: Motions, orders and resolutions.

[Caraviello]: 21-023 offered by Councilor Marks be it resolved that the deadline discount program be discussed.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Marks.

[Caraviello]: Second.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: On the motion by Councilor Marks, seconded by Councilor Knight.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Yes, affirmative motion passes.

[Caraviello]: 21038 offered by Vice President Knight and Councilor Scarpelli.

[Caraviello]: Resolution urging fair and full employment opportunity at Amazon.

[Caraviello]: Whereas Amazon has targeted the city of Medford expansion of its e-commerce network, and whereas COVID-19 has had a devastating impact on the health, safety, and well-being of the residents of the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: And whereas the preventative measures put in place to combat COVID-19 by state and local guidelines to prevent the spread and contain the transmission of the coronavirus have had a devastating

[Caraviello]: economic impact on local retail establishments in the city of Medfordians have changed the retail options for the residents of the city of Medfordians, whereas preventative measures put in place to combat COVID-19, and whereas

[Caraviello]: existing retail and e-commerce delivery networks currently operate in the city of Medford and set community standards for every family with sustaining wages, benefits, including but not limited to quality health insurance and secure retirement.

[Caraviello]: And whereas these retail and e-commerce delivery options coexist in Medford's diverse neighborhoods while adding value to the fabric of the community offering

[Caraviello]: good careers for Medford residents to provide for their families.

[Caraviello]: And whereas existing e-commerce delivery options have aptly served the residents of the city of Medford throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, while maintaining the highest standards for its essential workforce.

[Caraviello]: And whereas Amazon, which is not conformed to area standards for wages, benefits, and working condition, has targeted the city of Medford area for expansion of its e-commerce operations.

[Caraviello]: Now, be it resolved,

[Caraviello]: that the Medford City Council, hereby assembled, urges Amazon to meet and confer with the Medford community, included but not limited to representatives from the International Brotherhood of Teamsters Local 25, locally impacted neighborhood groups, local residents, and other interested parties to discuss how Amazon can expand the delivery options, warehouses, and fulfillment centers in a way that is beneficial to the city of Medford and its residents while guaranteeing

[Caraviello]: sustainable growth for the city in helping to ensure that fair and equitable employment standards are maintained for all e-commerce delivery networks throughout the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: And it be further resolved that prior to any expansion into the city of Medford, Amazon commits to and presents sufficient evidence to the Medford City Council that its operation meets or exceeds current standards set by existing e-commerce delivery networks.

[Caraviello]: This commitment would include that all delivery drivers be direct employees of Amazon and not independent contractors.

[Caraviello]: Amazon will ensure that all employee delivery drivers pass the most rigorous background checks, including COVID checks and are compliant with all federal DOT drug testing guidelines.

[Caraviello]: Amazon will only hire competent and safe delivery drivers that will maintain the utmost

[Caraviello]: professional conduct in their day-to-day operation in the neighborhoods of the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Knight.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Morell.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Councilor Bears.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: And if I if I could say something.

[Caraviello]: I want to thank Councilor Knight, Vice President Knight, and Councilor Scott Blake for bringing this forward.

[Caraviello]: These men and women who work for Amazon, I know they classify them as independent contractors.

[Caraviello]: They're not.

[Caraviello]: Because independent contractors can set their own time.

[Caraviello]: Amazon is a very demanding company, and they set the standard of how these men and women have to work, their hours, and their pay.

[Caraviello]: So they're not independent contractors.

[Caraviello]: All Amazon is doing

[Caraviello]: is avoiding paying them workman's comp, and insurance, and a decent living wage, and some type of pension.

[Caraviello]: So again, I also support this, not only for what they do in Medford, but for all the men and women who work for this company throughout the country, not just in Medford.

[Caraviello]: The same thing goes for the Uber and the Lyft guys.

[Caraviello]: Those guys, they're not independent contractors when you're dictated to how you have to work.

[Caraviello]: So again, I thank my councilors for bringing this up and I will be in support of this.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Councilor Falco.

[Caraviello]: Any further discussion on this?

[Caraviello]: President.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Marks.

[Caraviello]: We've asked them to appear before us to discuss the issues that have been brought up by the council.

[Caraviello]: So I'm sure that the clerk will send this out via registered mail so we know that someone has received it.

[Caraviello]: and have them appear before us.

[Caraviello]: Okay, we'll look into that and see if we can find anything.

[Caraviello]: We can also refer this to our solicitor also, RKP Law, for their opinion on the next step.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Vice President Knight.

[Caraviello]: Any further questions on this?

[Caraviello]: I don't see any.

[Caraviello]: Laura Ruma.

[Caraviello]: If we can unmute Laura.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, if we can unmute, thank you.

[Caraviello]: I got it, thank you.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Laura.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Morell.

[Caraviello]: I think Vice President Knight is asking mostly about the independent contractors that are in there.

[Caraviello]: I think that's really the highlight of it.

[Caraviello]: And I am aware that they do have an office over in Rivers Edge and Cabot Road, and they do employ people there in that office there.

[Caraviello]: So I thank you.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: 2-1-0-4-1, offered by Vice President Knight.

[Caraviello]: Whereas Council Paper 20-426 establishing the Cannabis Advisory Committee Ordinance was passed on September 22, 2020, and whereas Article 1 of this ordinance reads,

[Caraviello]: Within 90 days following the adoption of this, requires that the Cannabis Advisory Commission shall establish a scoring system and will review and score applicants seeking to locate a marijuana establishment in the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: Applications for all applicants shall be open no later than 120 days following the adoption of this order.

[Caraviello]: And whereas on Monday, December 21st, 2020,

[Caraviello]: mark the 90th day following passage of paper 20426.

[Caraviello]: And January 20th, 2021, mark the 120th day following this passage of paper 20426.

[Caraviello]: Be it further, be it so resolved that the presence of the members of the community, CAC is requested at the next regularly scheduled city council meeting for the purpose of a presentation consisting of the following materials and information.

[Caraviello]: copy of the scoring system, and application criteria being utilized by the CAC.

[Caraviello]: Two, the date the CAC began accepting applications.

[Caraviello]: Three, the deadline for the close of the application period.

[Caraviello]: Four, a two-date reporting of the number of applications received, number of interviews conducted, and the dates the interviews were held.

[Caraviello]: Five,

[Caraviello]: the proposed public meeting schedule for further notice, for further interview applicants.

[Caraviello]: Six.

[Caraviello]: Anticipated date that the CAC will present its findings and make recommendations regarding which respondents should be engaged to negotiate a host agreement and be it further resolved that the city council receive a legal opinion from the city solicitor on the following question.

[Caraviello]: Is the city exposed to any liabilities or legal ramifications should the CAC fail to act within the established timeframes outlined in the city ordinance?

[Caraviello]: 21042, offered by Vice President Knight.

[Caraviello]: Whereas the City of Medford is in the process of conducting an evaluation of the parking practices for review by the Traffic Commission, be it so resolved that the Medford City Council requests that the Traffic Commission examine the feasibility of establishing a temporary overnight parking pass for commercial vehicles that meet the following criteria.

[Caraviello]: One,

[Caraviello]: The applicant is proper licensed to operate the vehicle.

[Caraviello]: Two, the applicant's driver's license indicates MedFed residency.

[Caraviello]: Three, the applicant operates a commercial vehicle that is registered at an owner-occupied residence matching the address on the driver's license.

[Caraviello]: Four, the applicant is in possession of a valid building permit for construction for the owner-occupied residence that matches the address on the driver's license and vehicle registration.

[Caraviello]: The applicant in possession of a valid in driveway construction dumpster permit for the owner-occupied resident that matches the address on the driver's license, vehicle registration and building permit for construction and whereas the intent of this request is to provide, examine an option for temporary relief to a very small subset of residential property owners that meet a very specific set of criteria.

[Caraviello]: Be it further resolved

[Caraviello]: that the Traffic Commission consider safeguards that strike a fair balance between policy and neighborhood impact, including a public hearing process, prior to emissions, a limit on the number of consecutive days and total days in the calendar year, restricting vehicle sizes and requiring that the vehicle be located within a reasonable proximity to the address on the driver's license vehicle registration in the city premise.

[Caraviello]: Vice President Knight.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Morell.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. Vice President.

[Caraviello]: Good luck.

[Caraviello]: I look forward to seeing you.

[Caraviello]: Good luck.

[Caraviello]: Fourth regular meeting of the Medford City Council, January 26, 2001, 2021.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Present.

[Caraviello]: Present.

[Caraviello]: Present.

[Caraviello]: Assembly members present, please rise and salute the flag.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, I got to read the speech first.

[Caraviello]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: Specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirements to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medford.org.

[Caraviello]: For this meeting, the members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Caraviello]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Caraviello]: In the event that we're able to do so, despite best efforts,

[Caraviello]: We will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Markswell.

[Caraviello]: Motion to suspend the rules?

[Caraviello]: Motion by Council Marks to suspend the rules to take the paper from the community preservation committee that we did not finish.

[Caraviello]: Seconded by Councilor Scarpelli.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Seven in the affirmative, motion passes.

[Caraviello]: Public participation will be for a synopsis of the myth of the Community Preservation Committee discussion on the Thomas Brooks Master Implementation Plan Phase One.

[Caraviello]: In 2019, the Method Historical Commission was awarded a $25,000 grant to develop a master plan for the Thomas Brooks Park.

[Caraviello]: The master plan is now complete and the Method Historical Commission is applying for phase one of the implementation.

[Caraviello]: Based on the recommendations from the landscape architect, the Method Historical Committee is proposing phase one to include, one, slave wall restoration, two, ecological dig, three, rebuild of the field stone wall on Grove Street,

[Caraviello]: and edging cleanup and removal of invasive species along the field stone wall.

[Caraviello]: We have Jennifer Keenan in attendance to give us a synopsis of this plan.

[Caraviello]: Jennifer, are you here?

[Caraviello]: Okay, the clerk will unmute him.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Carr, are you on the call?

[Caraviello]: I am on the call.

[Caraviello]: Name and address of the record, please.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. Carr.

[Caraviello]: If you could give us a brief synopsis of the Thomas Brooks Master Plan Implementation Phase Two.

[Caraviello]: Sure.

[Caraviello]: I'm sorry, I didn't hear what you said.

[Caraviello]: 21037 to President Richard Caraviello and honorable members of the City Council, Premier Breanna Lungo-Koehn, RE, licensing of food trucks.

[Caraviello]: Dear President Caraviello and members of the Medford City Council, I respectfully request that the City Council approve the following request for a food truck at the Andrews School.

[Caraviello]: Due to the COVID-19 pandemic and the city's temporary policies limiting events and gatherings, the attached application includes some unique considerations which have been reviewed and approved by my office as well as the Board of Health.

[Caraviello]: This is a request for two food trucks to be stationed at the Andrews School for pickup of pre-ordered dinner items.

[Caraviello]: No congregating will be allowed as part of this plan.

[Caraviello]: Medford Streets, food truck for the PTO fundraiser.

[Caraviello]: Date, February 10th, 2021.

[Caraviello]: Time, 4 to 7 p.m.

[Caraviello]: Setup begins at 3 o'clock.

[Caraviello]: Location, Andrews Middle School.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Motion passes.

[Caraviello]: Meeting adjourned.

[Caraviello]: Good evening.

[Caraviello]: The third regular meeting of the City Council, January 19, 2021.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Present.

[Caraviello]: Present.

[Caraviello]: Present.

[Caraviello]: Please rise and salute the flag.

[Caraviello]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, general law chapter 38, section 18, and the governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Caraviello]: This meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: Specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and their parties with the right and the requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.MedfordMA.org.

[Caraviello]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Caraviello]: No person in attendance or members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Caraviello]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Bedford or on the community media

[Caraviello]: website, an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive recording of the meeting as soon as possible.

[Caraviello]: All right.

[Caraviello]: Motion to authorize the resolutions.

[Caraviello]: 21021 offered by Councilor Marks.

[Caraviello]: Specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement

[Caraviello]: to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medford.org.

[Caraviello]: contained in the link herein.

[Caraviello]: 21016 offered by Councilor Maks and Councilor Scarpelli be it resolved that the most recent site is posted on Governor's Ave, Lawrence Road and Forest Street be discussed.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Maks.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Councilor Marksley.

[Caraviello]: If I can be moved by Councilor Scarpelli, I'd like to read into a record a letter from the Lawrence Memorial Hospital.

[Caraviello]: Dear President Caraviello, we are writing in response to an agenda item that was brought to our attention on January 12th at the Medford City Council meeting.

[Caraviello]: Item 21016 calls to the attention a four-speed

[Caraviello]: feedback signs placed on Governor's Ave, Lawrence Road, and Lawrence Memorial Hospital campus, as part of the speed reduction efforts developed in coordination with the Medford Traffic Commission.

[Caraviello]: These four signs were inadvertently installed in the wrong location due to a miscommunication with the subcontractor.

[Caraviello]: Upon hearing the signs were installed in the wrong locations, we worked to rectify the situation.

[Caraviello]: The four signs were reinstalled in the locations previously approved by the city of Medford on January 11th.

[Caraviello]: We are sending a notice to our email distribution, notifying them of the error and the correction.

[Caraviello]: We apologize for any inconvenience this may have caused.

[Caraviello]: The installation of speed feedback signs is part of the traffic mitigation requested within the special permit.

[Caraviello]: We are pleased that this work has been completed in collaboration with the Bepatrack Traffic Commission in response to the community's request.

[Caraviello]: As shared in our end of the year notice, the construction of the new inventory care center is now completed.

[Caraviello]: The hospital's main lobby renovation is still underway and scheduled to be finished next month.

[Caraviello]: And a seasonal landscape and another final parking lot finish will be completed in the spring.

[Caraviello]: Currently, our efforts and resources are focused on the present COVID-19 surge, but we look forward to providing regular updates at future council meetings

[Caraviello]: and continue to engage our community advisory group.

[Caraviello]: Respectfully, Ryan Fuller, Vice President of Strategy and Business Planning, Melrose-Wayfield Healthcare.

[Caraviello]: I just want to read that into the record.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: On the motion by Councilor Marks, as amended by Councilor Marks, seconded by Councilor Scarpelli.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Communications from the mayor.

[Caraviello]: I'm sorry, Councilor, by the way, we've disposed of it.

[Caraviello]: If you can come back after, I appreciate it.

[Caraviello]: You can come back during public participation.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Communications from the Mayor, 21018, January 8th, 2020, and to the Honorable President, members of the City Council, City Hall, Mifflin Mass, I read, Personnel Ordinance.

[Caraviello]: Dear Mr. President and Councilors, I respectfully request and recommend that Your Honorable Body approve the following amendments to the revised ordinance entitled Personnel Article Two, Classification and Compensation Plan, section 66-33, entitled, Officers, Employees, Non-Union, by adding

[Caraviello]: new positions of Director of Economic Development and Director of Diversity and Human Resources to the following classification.

[Caraviello]: Amendment A, classifications CAF 15, presently state that this applies as the following.

[Caraviello]: CAF 15, sealer of weights and measures, recreation director and director of communications.

[Caraviello]: The language of CAF 15 shall be amended to read as the following.

[Caraviello]: CAF 15, sealer of weights and measures, recreation director, director of communications, and director of economic developments.

[Caraviello]: Amendment B, classification CAF 19 presently states that it applies as follows.

[Caraviello]: CAF 19, city clerk, treasurer collector, director of the budget, CPO, director of

[Caraviello]: Public Health and Elder Services, Chief Assessor.

[Caraviello]: The language of CAF 19 shall be amended to read as follows.

[Caraviello]: CAF 19, City Clerk, Treasurer Collector, Director of Budget, CPO, Director of Public Health and Elder Services, Chief Assessor, Director of Diversity and Human Resource, respectively submitted Brianna Lungo, current Mayor.

[Caraviello]: We have Dave Rodriguez from the administration.

[Caraviello]: Dave, would you like to speak on this?

[Caraviello]: Councilor Knight.

[Caraviello]: Motion.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[Caraviello]: Five in affirmative, two in the negative.

[Caraviello]: Motion passes.

[Caraviello]: If I could turn the chair over to Vice President Knight.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: This is a project that we just got through doing about a month ago.

[Caraviello]: And if you drive by there, the paint is already wearing off on the crosswalks and some of the siding there.

[Caraviello]: Come the spring, I'd hate to see it after our DPW guys go out there and do it.

[Caraviello]: So I would ask that the administration have the DOT come back in the spring and repaint that whole area on Mystic Avenue that they just recently painted.

[Caraviello]: I mean, you paint it in the middle of the winter, the paint's not gonna last too long.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: President, we have these 40Bs that are currently on appeal here.

[Caraviello]: And a couple of weeks ago, our own OCP director had stated that we are under the affordable number needed to stop these, and we are also not close to the glam number to stop these.

[Caraviello]: I mean, tonight we talked about affordable housing all year long.

[Caraviello]: We've been talking about affordable housing, affordable housing.

[Caraviello]: Well, unfortunately, right now this is our only avenue to get affordable housing in the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: And are we fighting a fight that we can't win here?

[Caraviello]: I mean, I know we had Judy Barrett in the picture for a while there.

[Caraviello]: I don't know if she's still working for the city.

[Caraviello]: I know she was a master at negotiating friendly 40 B's, but I don't know where we are now.

[Caraviello]: I mean, are we just, I hate to see us continue spending money on legal costs on fights that we can't win.

[Caraviello]: I know Mr. Rodriguez is on the call here.

[Caraviello]: If he'd like to give an opinion on where we stand on this.

[Caraviello]: have we begun any negotiation with the three groups?

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: I mean, again, I say, I know, you know, the numbers aren't working out in our favor.

[Caraviello]: I mean, the numbers that the state came back with and the numbers that the city have, we're not even in the same ballpark with this.

[Caraviello]: So I'd hate to see us,

[Caraviello]: just spin our wheels here and spend money on legal costs that aren't going anywhere.

[Caraviello]: And we're losing tax dollars on these projects also.

[Caraviello]: I mean, as soon as one of them goes up, we gain a million dollars in tax revenue, not counting the building payment fee on each building.

[Caraviello]: And we help with affordable housing.

[Caraviello]: So I don't know why,

[Caraviello]: I don't know what the holdup is and why we want to continue to fight these.

[Caraviello]: Because if you follow the trends right now, commercial property around the Boston area is going by the wayside and it's going toward housing.

[Caraviello]: Because the new business model is not people going back to work in the businesses.

[Caraviello]: So you're going to see a big downturn in commercial.

[Caraviello]: And I hate to see these people walk out of town and leave us with properties doing nothing.

[Caraviello]: So I'll leave it to my other councilors for any further discussion.

[Caraviello]: Chair recognizes Councilor Falco.

[Caraviello]: I would be amenable to that Councilor Falco.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: When I put this on, I did hear from Chief of Staff Rodriguez,

[Caraviello]: this morning, and he let me know that a company has been secured to do the cleanup of the station, because I have been hearing from offices about how the trash had already been piling up in the station.

[Caraviello]: And they're asking why, when one of their employees in the office gets sick, the office isn't shut down.

[Caraviello]: He's ushered us into a whole new period of a way of living and how these meetings are conducted throughout, not just our meetings, but meetings throughout the whole city in this difficult time.

[Caraviello]: I mean, he's been here many hours with us, day and night.

[Caraviello]: And if we can get a report back the next meeting on how much money is left in that account.

[Caraviello]: that we appropriated money to, and make that part of the bring here.

[Caraviello]: But as I say, I haven't seen a lot of people filing for that money.

[Caraviello]: So again, I would hope that if people are in trouble, there's money there, there's assistance there, they should be taking advantage of it.

[Caraviello]: So as I say, Mr. Clerk, if you can make that part of this report, we can report back on how much money is left in that fund.

[Caraviello]: for the rental assistance.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Before we do the records.

[Caraviello]: for your leadership over the last two years.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: And it's been a difficult, this year's been a very difficult one for you.

[Caraviello]: So again, I wanna thank you for your leadership over the last two years, and I hope I can hold up to the same high standards that you've done over this time.

[Caraviello]: So I thank you, and good work.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, I found the records to be accurate and precise.

[Caraviello]: And motion for approval.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, if I could take a moment to thank all the residents in this community who've come out to support all the non-profit organizations with gifts, food and everything.

[Caraviello]: In my 30 years of doing community work, I've always found that people come out more.

[Caraviello]: And when times are tough, then when times are good.

[Caraviello]: And as I say, there's the Rotary, the Kiwanis, the Family Network, all these organizations, they put food, they put a lot of time and effort into making sure that a lot of families, Medford families, were taken care of this year with toys and all kinds of essentials.

[Caraviello]: So again, thank you to all the residents who came out and supported everybody to make sure that everybody in this community

[Caraviello]: has a good Christmas.

[Caraviello]: So again, thank you to everybody.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Motion to take papers under suspension, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: from John over the years.

[Caraviello]: John, he was a Medford Square staple as long as I can remember.

[Caraviello]: I remember when I was young, I got my haircut there.

[Caraviello]: He was doing hairstyling when it wasn't even fashionable to do hairstyling.

[Caraviello]: And now he's finally hanging up his scissors after 50 plus years of cutting people's hair.

[Caraviello]: I'm going to support Councilor Marks on his issue with the election coordinator.

[Caraviello]: As we see as we just got through an election throughout the country, elections have become more complex than they've ever been.

[Caraviello]: And the longer we wait to fund this position, the harder it's going to be.

[Caraviello]: Because again, not only are we going to need a coordinator, but the rules and the way we've done the elections over the years have vastly changed over the last four or five years.

[Caraviello]: And again, it's time that we bring our election department up to the standard that it needs to be.

[Caraviello]: And let's say, if we're going to wait until after this election, and then before you know it, it'll be after January, and before you know it,

[Caraviello]: The new election is going to be around the corner, and we're going to be still arguing about this.

[Caraviello]: So I'm not going to support anything that doesn't have the election coordinator in this package here, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Motions, orders, and resolutions 20624 offered by President Falco be it resolved that as this meeting of the Medford City Council is taking place on November 10th, the 245th birthday of the United States Marines and on the eve of Veterans Day, that these proceedings be dedicated in appreciation to the many contributions of all veterans, especially all

[Caraviello]: Method women and men who have served us in the Army, Navy, Marines, Air Force, Coast Guard, and National Guard.

[Caraviello]: This service has provided all of us with the freedoms that we enjoy, freedom of speech, freedom of press, freedom of assembly, freedom of worship, and the due process of law.

[Caraviello]: And further, that on this day, the Medford City Council extend happy birthday wishes to all Method residents who have served us in the United States Marines.

[Caraviello]: As Marine Commander John

[Caraviello]: Lejeune said that when the state was first recognized, since the birth of the corps, Marines have acquitted themselves with great distinction under the term Marine has come to signify all that is the highest in military efficiency,

[Caraviello]: and soldierly virtue.

[Caraviello]: President Falco.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, I sympathize with Council Marks and the people doing it in the park.

[Caraviello]: I live on a street that's got a four-way stop sign.

[Caraviello]: There's not even a stop sign there.

[Caraviello]: Before, people used to slow down when they went through it.

[Caraviello]: They just don't even, I mean, I can see them going down the street.

[Caraviello]: I mean, they're not even putting the foot in the brake.

[Caraviello]: I don't know if it's the way people just driving nowadays.

[Caraviello]: Everyone's in a hurry, more than they've ever been.

[Caraviello]: And part of the problem is you've got so many more delivery drivers now.

[Caraviello]: Not only in trucks, but like DoorDash, GrubHub, all these things.

[Caraviello]: These guys are all trying to make a buck during these times, I know it's tough.

[Caraviello]: You see them, they just fly through these stop signs, and there's no consideration for the neighborhood.

[Caraviello]: And I live a block from the Brooks School, and even during school times, no one stops at these signs anymore.

[Caraviello]: I hope that the traffic department can figure something out to slow these people down in the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: President, we have one of the highest assessments in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts for the T. I would hope that if there's going to be cuts, I would hope that our contribution to the T also gets reduced.

[Caraviello]: I mean, every time we turn around, they're hitting us for more money, and more money, and more money, and not providing the service that they were promised.

[Caraviello]: If cuts are made, I would hope that our contribution also gets cut, what we pay.

[Caraviello]: Because I think we're the fourth or fifth highest payer to the T. Vice President Caraviello, good point, and you are 100% correct.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: I just want to thank my two Councilors for bringing this forward.

[Caraviello]: I have known the Crowley's for many years, the little league fields with their kids.

[Caraviello]: Good family, always running, see them everywhere.

[Caraviello]: 50 years, I hope I'm only five behind them.

[Caraviello]: I just want to congratulate them on their 50th anniversary.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, I think in the last year, we are now the tractor trailer parking capital of the state.

[Caraviello]: Commercial Street, which used to have one or two trucks parked there, is now lined.

[Caraviello]: We had tractor trailers, every day, every, it's to the point where they're now a disturbance to the businesses that are over there.

[Caraviello]: The tractor trailers are parking on Route 16, all along the city yet.

[Caraviello]: Now they're parking on the grass and back of the city yet.

[Caraviello]: I mean, these guys with these stripes, I don't know if they live in Medford, if they're based in Medford, but it's about time that they're going to have to find a place to park and pay like other people do.

[Caraviello]: We're out there tagging the Johnny Diploma.

[Caraviello]: who parks his plumbing truck on the street and he's getting hit with overnight tickets.

[Caraviello]: So it's good for one and it's good for another.

[Caraviello]: These trucks are just, they're overwhelming our city now.

[Caraviello]: It's about time they find a place to park and not on our streets, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, this is a small garage that was operated by Bob Libby for probably the last 30, 40 years that I can remember.

[Caraviello]: And again, I think it's just about, it's a small garage, I think one day, that's really about it.

[Caraviello]: So just a small auto repair that he's purchasing from Bob Libby.

[Caraviello]: And I don't think he's doing anything different than Bob Libby was doing.

[Caraviello]: Number 11.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: To Councilor Bears, last question.

[Caraviello]: Linden Street was resurfaced about a year ago.

[Caraviello]: So that's part of my question is, is any of this going to be going into Locust Street?

[Caraviello]: There's Italian.

[Caraviello]: Which brings me to my next question, which Councilor Marks brought up.

[Caraviello]: Why are we doing this project now, or why didn't we do it before?

[Caraviello]: Because we've just gone through paving Loca Street, like two weeks ago.

[Caraviello]: So now the brand new paved street is gonna get dug up.

[Caraviello]: Linden Street was just recently paved.

[Caraviello]: That's gonna get dug up.

[Caraviello]: And the other thing is, we're doing this in the middle of the winter.

[Caraviello]: I mean, not in the middle of the winter, but the side of the winter.

[Caraviello]: When people depend on the heat, three or four hours might be a long time if you've got kids at home.

[Caraviello]: Not that I want to be the bearer of bad news, but three weeks ago, National Grid did a project on Winford Way and they forgot to put the gas on.

[Caraviello]: I got a call at like 7.30 at night and trying to find someone to get down there at 9 o'clock at night to put the gas on for every resident was a monumental task.

[Caraviello]: And some of them didn't get the gas on the whole night.

[Caraviello]: So that has my concern also.

[Caraviello]: We're doing this in the cold weather, you're going to be digging up the streets, and the patch you're going to put down is going to be of substance to the project, because all the plants get closed in the winter.

[Caraviello]: So this is going to be a temporary patch, it's going to snow, and before the end of the winter, it's going to be all dug up again.

[Caraviello]: That's really what I'm concerned about, why this has to get done now in the winter.

[Caraviello]: And also, you're doing it in the holiday season, so now you're going to block Walker Street, where there's a shopping center, and the Felsbury Plaza.

[Caraviello]: I mean, these stores are hurting enough.

[Caraviello]: And this is their little bit of time to get some business back is November,

[Caraviello]: And we're shutting one of their main streets down.

[Caraviello]: So I've got concerns about the timing of this project also, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Request for appropriation of Community Preservation Committee.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President and city councilors, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approve the following recommendation of the Community Preservation Committee.

[Caraviello]: Number one, requesting the appropriation of $125,000 from the Community Preservation Act, Community Housing Reserve to the Action for Boston Community Development

[Caraviello]: for ABCD rental assistance for Medford Residence Program.

[Caraviello]: Number two, requesting the appropriation of $2,835 from the CPA General Reserve to the City of Medford Department of Veterans Services to restore the USMCKA Markey Memorial located at the intersection of Lawrence Road and Winthrop Street.

[Caraviello]: Number three,

[Caraviello]: requesting the appropriation of $3,500 from the CPA General Reserve to the trees, Medford slash City of Medford Tree Warden to undertake an inventory of all existing trees located in Oak Row Cemetery.

[Caraviello]: All projects will be tracked in the Community Preservation Fund by category, Community Hazard Reserve, and General Reserve.

[Caraviello]: Lucille Tonello was a crossing guide for the city of Medford for many years.

[Caraviello]: She was supervisor of the crossing guides.

[Caraviello]: And Lucille goes back to the days when kids actually walked to school.

[Caraviello]: And you had the same crossing guard for many years, and she knew your parents, and she knew the kids by name, and they wore uniforms, and they were almost like policemen.

[Caraviello]: And they march in the parade, so that's a generation of a woman that's no longer around anymore.

[Caraviello]: But let's say, you know, she was there all the time for these kids, you know, watched over them.

[Caraviello]: Parents would call her.

[Caraviello]: to make sure, hey, I'm not going to be home, make sure Johnny gets home.

[Caraviello]: She would do that, and many times, she would drive the kids home.

[Caraviello]: So like I say, she goes back to that generation of the crossing guards, where I say, why are you in the farms?

[Caraviello]: And I say, they knew the neighbor, they knew the kids, they knew the parents.

[Caraviello]: And she's a good woman, and I got to know her over the years, and her presence will be missed in our community.

[Caraviello]: And condolences to the family.

[Caraviello]: A motion that we hold this meeting in her honor.

[Caraviello]: For those of you who don't know Mary, Mary Burns is a long time resident.

[Caraviello]: She just passed away at 96 years old.

[Caraviello]: Mary Chevrier Road, lived there many, many years, and business owner of a restaurant in Davis Square for a long time.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Chosey has turned 101 this year.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Chosey was born during the largest pandemic in the history of our country, with the Spanish flu, where close to 100 million people died.

[Caraviello]: And he survived that.

[Caraviello]: He was also an Army World War II veteran.

[Caraviello]: And here we are.

[Caraviello]: To the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, City of Medford, proposed ordinance, Historic District, dear Mr. President and members of the City Council, I respectfully request and recommend that your Honorable body approve the following amendments to the City of Medford revised ordinance entitled, Historic District Commission Article 3, Section 48-51, as described below.

[Caraviello]: These amendments clarify the ordinance to delineate the previous approved

[Caraviello]: districts, and at the request of the Medford Historic District Commission, create a new single parcel historic district at 16 Foster Court.

[Caraviello]: By way of background, section 48, that's 51A, under the authority of Master General Law, section chapter 40, section 3, there is hereby established a Hillside Avenue

[Caraviello]: On the motion by Councilor Naito, waive the reading, seconded by?

[Caraviello]: Second.

[Caraviello]: Seconded by Councilor Miz.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: I think Mr. President, Mr. Bailey mentioned it's a procedure.

[Caraviello]: And I think the whole thing here is because of the procedure.

[Caraviello]: The historical group was tasked five years ago to go out and identify historical pieces of property.

[Caraviello]: And currently, the procedure is, you buy the property for us, and then we'll tell you if it's historical.

[Caraviello]: That's- I mean, this is not the procedure that you should have.

[Caraviello]: Point of information.

[Caraviello]: Point of information, Councilor Bears.

[Caraviello]: Vice President Caraviello, please continue.

[Caraviello]: Again, it's a procedure.

[Caraviello]: That's the problem.

[Caraviello]: It's not whether the district is good or bad, it's a procedure.

[Caraviello]: This property was purchased 18 months ago.

[Caraviello]: They didn't get around to it until month 16.

[Caraviello]: So now the burden is on us, because everyone sat on it for a year and a half, all this time, and now the burden is on this group to do a last minute decision.

[Caraviello]: Where were you the last 16 months negotiating with this guy?

[Caraviello]: Did nothing happen during the 16 months that you had to wait until August 28th, the end of the August meeting, to decide that you wanted to make this a historical news?

[Caraviello]: Why couldn't you have decided that in February of 19, when this was put in?

[Caraviello]: So I don't think it's fair to this group to put us in this position that wasn't created by us.

[Caraviello]: Well, if there's so many properties, why aren't you identifying them?

[Caraviello]: Where's the list?

[Caraviello]: I haven't seen a list.

[Caraviello]: I don't think anybody in this group has seen a list of properties that have been identified.

[Caraviello]: Again, until you guys come up with a procedure, this is going to happen every time somebody buys a property.

[Caraviello]: Again, 16 months has gone by, 17 months has gone by, and now we're here at the 18th hour with the panic being put on us.

[Caraviello]: Okay, thank you.

[Caraviello]: On the motion of

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Councilman Knox, I'm sorry, Councilman Nutt is 100% right.

[Caraviello]: We'll make it through this year with what we have, but next year is going to be a very trying year for us.

[Caraviello]: Monies that we've normally had in the past aren't going to be coming in.

[Caraviello]: restaurants, sales, all these little things.

[Caraviello]: And your building department generates millions of dollars in building permits for the city.

[Caraviello]: Like it or not, development is a necessary part of the growth of a community, no matter what kind.

[Caraviello]: And here we are.

[Caraviello]: We're stunting growth in this community, even on these small projects.

[Caraviello]: So again, I support Councilor Knight on this, and I'll second the motion from this.

[Caraviello]: But again, we have to look for ways to generate money for this community, and we can't be chasing people away from this community.

[Caraviello]: So we need to start embracing some things.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Thank you for bringing this up.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, this is going to be a question coming down the line for the next year or so with the proliferation of 40B projects coming into the city of Medford until we reach our threshold.

[Caraviello]: I was able to watch the meeting a couple of weeks ago.

[Caraviello]: when the decision came in in favor of the petitioner at 4000 Mystic Valley Parkway.

[Caraviello]: And one of the big questions was, the formula that's used between the city of Medford number and the Commonwealth of Massachusetts number, along with the private petitioner's numbers, we were off about 70 points, which is a huge discrepancy.

[Caraviello]: So that's somewhat of a concern to me.

[Caraviello]: The Board of Appeals has appealed that decision to the next level.

[Caraviello]: How are we funding this appeal, Mr. President, is my first question.

[Caraviello]: Is this going to cost us money if we hire a separate attorney to do this appeal?

[Caraviello]: And second, we have two more petitioners right behind this one here, one being on the Felsway, where the box factory is, and another one

[Caraviello]: being on Mystic Avenue.

[Caraviello]: So I know this first project doesn't get us to our limit and maybe the next two will.

[Caraviello]: Seeing that these are uh, I mean, is the city gonna deny those because I don't see the state using a different formula to uh, They're on on those two, uh applicants any different than they did on the first one so, uh, uh, are we going to appeal all those or are we going to maybe try to negotiate a a uh, some type of settlement with these, uh people to get up to our uh,

[Caraviello]: our our thresholds because uh again uh in a long uh with the new census coming out our threshold may go higher so that's something we have to keep an eye out for um but do we have any other you know does the administration have a plan to uh for affordable housing i mean uh

[Caraviello]: Right now, this is the only avenue that we currently have for affordable housing in the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: I don't see the federal government coming forward and building any housing projects similar to what they did on Willis Avenue or Riverside Avenue.

[Caraviello]: So again, on the other side of this, these three projects, if the city were to embrace them,

[Caraviello]: uh in these uh difficult times would probably generate just in building fees mr president uh over two million dollars which uh uh would wipe out our deficit that the the building department is currently facing uh with the building premise and along with putting some boots on the ground people working in the city of medford so um again this is a this is a discussion we have to have going forward

[Caraviello]: to how do we get to our thresholds without allowing these projects to come forward?

[Caraviello]: So I'll leave that up to my other Councilors for discussion.

[Caraviello]: Vice President Caraviello.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: One thing I didn't mention that the last three projects that came on board in the city of Medford, which is River's Edge, Modera, and the other River's Edge have generated close to $3 million in taxes.

[Caraviello]: for our city, which is a far cry more than we were getting for those properties in the state that they were.

[Caraviello]: And like I said, these three projects would probably generate three to four million.

[Caraviello]: So again, we're not looking at just today, Mr. President, we're looking at going down the line for the financial stability of our city.

[Caraviello]: Like I said, right now, we're in tough times, and like I said, just the zoning—I mean, excuse me, just the building fees are a tremendous amount of money.

[Caraviello]: Even if any of these projects were to start today, we wouldn't see any money on these probably till the next two years.

[Caraviello]: And again, like I say, the problem that we have today with our budget isn't going to be going away anytime soon.

[Caraviello]: So again, we have to look toward the future and generating more money for the city because unfortunately, we are a business and we do need to make money to keep on going.

[Caraviello]: It's just, we do need to generate money every year.

[Caraviello]: And I hear that, you know, we can, we can call it whatever we want, but we do money funds have to be, you know, the tax dollars only raise X amount of dollars.

[Caraviello]: So, uh, you know, new growth is, is a big, a big part of our budget every year.

[Caraviello]: Nope, Vice President Caraviello.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, if I could amend this to get a report from ABCD to find out how many calls from Methodist residents that have been received as of this date.

[Caraviello]: Again, I want to make sure that our residents are getting the benefit of this and not residents from other cities.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: And I thank my fellow Councilor for his diligent work here.

[Caraviello]: I agree with him.

[Caraviello]: This is a longstanding question.

[Caraviello]: It goes back and forth, back and forth, whether they are allowed or not allowed.

[Caraviello]: I think we have documentation saying that it is.

[Caraviello]: And again, if somebody wants to challenge this in the court of law, then I think it's time that they do so.

[Caraviello]: Other than that, I think the paperwork stands on its own.

[Caraviello]: And I think we should move on from there.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: A lot of good points were made tonight on all ends, and I don't think anybody wants to scare anybody.

[Caraviello]: But the reality...

[Caraviello]: tough times after we require tough decisions.

[Caraviello]: On the city end,

[Caraviello]: We're short on the DPW.

[Caraviello]: We're short everywhere.

[Caraviello]: What are we going to do?

[Caraviello]: Are we going to cut them?

[Caraviello]: I think our job is to figure out how to save their jobs and help with alternative revenue streams to keep these people's jobs and not have them be in fear of losing their jobs.

[Caraviello]: There are review streams out there that we haven't even looked at.

[Caraviello]: So again, I think if we have the information in front of us, we can make a better decision.

[Caraviello]: And then the MDC then was going to demolish the building.

[Caraviello]: I went to then Senator Shannon.

[Caraviello]: who helped secure the funding to keep La Conte Rink open, and it's still open today, thanks to the funding that Senator Shannon got to keep the building open.

[Caraviello]: Going forward, we end up becoming good friends, family friends, and he was a great senator, and again, probably taught me a lot of things that I've learned to make me the councilor that I am.

[Caraviello]: So I thank him, and thank council for bringing this forward.

[Caraviello]: I reviewed the records and they're in order.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, if I could ask, indulgence is one thing.
