[Caraviello]: Communications from the Mayor.

[Caraviello]: Dear Mr. President and City Councilors, I respectfully request and recommend that Your Honorable Body approve the following recommendation of the Community Preservation Committee, requesting the appropriation of $3,000 from the CPA General Reserve to Elyse Turner and Amishka Durali in association with the- Mr. President, if I may.

[Caraviello]: Oh, I'm sorry.

[Caraviello]: I apologize.

[Caraviello]: 2A2, give us a presence in council.

[Caraviello]: I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approve the following amendments to the revised ordinance entitled personnel article two, classification and communication plan section 66-33 entitled officers and employees non-union by adding new positions of

[Caraviello]: Director of Communications and Director of Community Fair to the following classifications.

[Caraviello]: Amendment A, classification CAF-15 presently states that it applies as follows.

[Caraviello]: CAF-15, sealer of weights and measures slash recreation director.

[Caraviello]: The language of CAF-15 shall be amended to read as follows.

[Caraviello]: CAF-15, sealer of weights and measures

[Caraviello]: Recreation Director, Director of Communications.

[Caraviello]: Amendment B. Classification CAF 11 presently states that it applies as following.

[Caraviello]: CAF 11, Assistant City Clerk.

[Caraviello]: The language of CAF 11 shall be amended to read as follows.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Last week at the MMA show, myself and President Falco had the opportunity to meet a company that does what they call Horton Place Mill Asphalt Recycling.

[Caraviello]: And what they do is they come and they grind and they take our asphalt that normally we would give back to the asphalt company and we would buy it back from them.

[Caraviello]: We would keep our own asphalt here.

[Caraviello]: They recycle it in place and heat it and it goes right back down on the road as soon as they do it.

[Caraviello]: It sounds like a very good cost saving plan because when we talk to them,

[Caraviello]: They gave us a price of somewhere around $25 a yard, which normally we pay $48 a yard.

[Caraviello]: So thinking outside of the box, we could probably do two streets for the price of one street.

[Caraviello]: So I think it's something that's worthwhile looking at.

[Caraviello]: I had the opportunity to speak with Steve Tanaya and

[Caraviello]: DPW director and they both liked it and they agreed that it's something that we should look into.

[Caraviello]: And I'll yield to President Falco.

[Caraviello]: In fact, we have a brochure.

[Caraviello]: We'll get some copies out to you.

[Caraviello]: They mill it, grind it, and heat it, and put it back down immediately as it's done.

[Caraviello]: And like I said, with Chapter 90 money being thin, I don't think this is something that you'd probably want to use like in High Street or Main Street.

[Caraviello]: But I think it'd be a worthwhile project to look at on some of the side streets that really need attention.

[Caraviello]: Normally when we do a street, they come and they grind it and maybe sit three, four, five, maybe a week before we get started.

[Caraviello]: This gets, as fast as it's ground, it's put right back down.

[Caraviello]: So I'm assuming they could probably do a street in a day or maybe more.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Knight.

[Caraviello]: Any idea what it costs?

[Caraviello]: Yes, it's, like I said, their projection was somewhere about $25 a yard or a foot.

[Caraviello]: No, for the machine.

[Caraviello]: I'm sorry?

[Caraviello]: To buy the machine.

[Caraviello]: This is something I brought up, I think, two weeks ago in regards to a couple of the boxes in the city that were strewn with trash all around them.

[Caraviello]: I got a call from a gentleman from Planet Aid explaining to me what happened.

[Caraviello]: and to get it cleaned up, but he had asked me why we don't have an ordinance in the city of Medford in regards to regulating these boxes.

[Caraviello]: And I didn't know.

[Caraviello]: And he, in turn, sent me a couple of ordinances from different cities.

[Caraviello]: And they were pretty good.

[Caraviello]: But what he explained to me is what's happening is there's people that come out with boxes.

[Caraviello]: And they just put them on people's property.

[Caraviello]: And people don't know.

[Caraviello]: A lot of people, they're absentee landlords or things.

[Caraviello]: They don't know where they came from.

[Caraviello]: And there's no identification of where the boxes are.

[Caraviello]: In fact, I didn't realize that Planet Aid

[Caraviello]: It's got six boxes in the city.

[Caraviello]: I don't know where they all are, but there's boxes out there.

[Caraviello]: There's boxes for books.

[Caraviello]: There's boxes for a lot of things.

[Caraviello]: But some of these companies that operate these are for profit.

[Caraviello]: They're not all non-profit organizations.

[Caraviello]: And what also happens is now they're becoming garbage dumps.

[Caraviello]: Because people have a television, they don't want to spend the $25 to get the ticket for waste manager to take it.

[Caraviello]: Or there's just toys that they can't fit in the barrel and the rubbish man won't take them.

[Caraviello]: And now these guys that own these bins, spending thousands and thousands of dollars.

[Caraviello]: to what started out as a good idea for donations, now they're becoming trash receptacles for people who have nowhere to go with their rubbish.

[Caraviello]: So I ask that the solicitor adopt an ordinance, and I have a couple that I'll forward to her that was given, and to establish a permit and fee process for the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: I will send her a couple of the ordinances that he sent me from a couple of different cities.

[Caraviello]: Other cities require them to put a point of contact on them and get permission from the property owner to put this box on so you know that it's in the right spot.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: similar to a project manager that we have in particular.

[Caraviello]: But this person here goes out and advocates for the city for the 40B projects.

[Caraviello]: Tonight we've invited Max Stevens here to receive a citation from the Medford City Council in recognition of him winning the gold medal in the Hockey Deaf Olympics that was held in Italy in December.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Thank you Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Max are you here?

[Caraviello]: There you are.

[Caraviello]: You can come up to the rails.

[Caraviello]: Thank you very much.

[Caraviello]: Tonight we are here to congratulate Max Stephens for being part of a team that won the

[Caraviello]: gold medal for hockey in the Deaf Olympics that were held in Italy this past December.

[Caraviello]: Max, for those of you who don't know, was only 17 years old and he participated on a team that had teammates 25 to 35 years old, which is somewhere 10 years older than Max.

[Caraviello]: Max played an integral part in this team.

[Caraviello]: I think his dad told me he got a couple of goals and he had a pretty good season.

[Caraviello]: Max has overcome his disability, for those of you who don't know, and this has come over the years.

[Caraviello]: I've known him since he was a little boy, but he's overcome this with a lot of hard work and dedication, and we're seeing the fruits of what's happened for the fine things that he's done.

[Caraviello]: When someone looks at the word disability, it immediately conjures up the idea of what someone could not do, or something physically wrong,

[Caraviello]: with that injury that prevents them from doing something as the majority of society can do.

[Caraviello]: Well, Max has proved everyone wrong, and being here tonight with his family and the gold medal is a tribute to his hard work and dedication.

[Caraviello]: Max, people will always remember your name, but your success today tells a story of your indomitable courage and your inspiration for others to follow.

[Caraviello]: Be the same forever and add many more feathers of success to your crown.

[Caraviello]: Congratulations to you and your family,

[Caraviello]: as you have done yourself, your family, and the city of Medford proud.

[Caraviello]: I want to congratulate you tonight.

[Caraviello]: And before I present you with the citation, I think some of our colleagues may have some words to congratulate you.

[Caraviello]: President Falco.

[Caraviello]: You should be on.

[Caraviello]: No?

[Caraviello]: All right.

[Caraviello]: What am I doing wrong here?

[Caraviello]: Should be on, no?

[Caraviello]: Two, Council President and members of the City Council, from Stephanie and Burt Mayer, acceptance of a grant from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and the National Park Service Land and Water Conservation Fund, phase one improvements to Harris Park, and to appropriate the funds necessary for the implementation of the project.

[Caraviello]: The Commonwealth of Massachusetts and the National Park Service have awarded a reimbursement grant of $300,000 in federal land and water conservation funds to the city for improvements to Harris Park to service residents.

[Caraviello]: Implementation of the project will cost an estimated $817,000, and this sum must be appropriately allocated to the project prior to the execution of the grant agreements.

[Caraviello]: The council has appropriated $300,000 in CPA funds to the project, leaving a balance of $517,050 to be appropriated prior to the execution of the grant agreement.

[Caraviello]: I respectfully request and recommend that your Honorable Body adopt the attempt resolution letter, resolution to finally accept the grant and to appropriate the sum of $570,000 for the implementation of the project.

[Caraviello]: The Federal Land and Water Conservation Fund grant will reimburse $300,000 on completion of the project.

[Caraviello]: Sincerely, Stephanie M. Burke, Mayor.

[Caraviello]: 18449, from Mayor Stephanie Burke.

[Caraviello]: I read amendment to the revised ordinance of the city of Medford establishing a revolving fund account in the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: Dear Mr. President and members of the city council, I respectfully request to recommend that your honorable body approve an amendment to the revised ordinances of the city of Medford establishing a new ordinance pertaining to revolving funds.

[Caraviello]: General law chapter 44, section 53E and a half permits the city to establish a revolving fund ordinance.

[Caraviello]: Any such ordinance must specify for each fund, one, the programs or activities for which the revolving fund may be expended.

[Caraviello]: Two, the departmental receipts in connection with those programs or activities that shall be credited to the revolving fund.

[Caraviello]: Three, the board, department, or officer authorized to expend

[Caraviello]: from such fund ends for any reporting or other requirements the city or town may impose.

[Caraviello]: The attached is the full text of the proposed amendment creating a revolving fund ordinance in the text of the provisions of the statute.

[Caraviello]: The Director of Finance and Auditing will be at attendance to answer any questions.

[Caraviello]: Good evening.

[Caraviello]: Name and address of the record, please.

[Caraviello]: On the motion by Councilor Dello Russo, seconded by Councilor Bailão.

[Caraviello]: All those in favor?

[Caraviello]: All those in favor?

[Caraviello]: Motion passes.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: 18-450.

[Caraviello]: Motion passes.

[Caraviello]: Reports of committee 17766, committee of the whole meeting from November 14th, 2017 regarding Enstar Eversource.

[Caraviello]: And I have the report here which I will read.

[Caraviello]: The purpose of the meeting was to receive a presentation from Eversource on their request for grants of location on the transmission project from moving through Medford.

[Caraviello]: The following recommendations were made.

[Caraviello]: That one, a traffic plan be submitted to the council and the police chief.

[Caraviello]: Two, construction schedule with start dates, days of weeks, and times be submitted.

[Caraviello]: Three, that Eversource set up an informational meeting at the high school to include

[Caraviello]: the winter street residents in a budding neighborhoods for that a contact name for the project with a telephone number and email be posted to the city's website.

[Caraviello]: Five that plans be provided by ever source on route on the route from question street to the city line that were included seven

[Caraviello]: Eversource develop a regional communication plan.

[Caraviello]: That plan would entail them developing a strategy of contacting TV and radio station, notifying non-Method residents about the project, and to notify them of alternate routes.

[Caraviello]: A motion was made by council tonight to send this report out.

[Caraviello]: Vice President Mox.

[Caraviello]: There was another missing somewhere along the line.

[Caraviello]: I think there was only supposed to be seven and it ended up being eight.

[Caraviello]: Was that the meeting from last week or the week before?

[Caraviello]: It was last week.

[Caraviello]: This is from two weeks ago.

[Caraviello]: Okay, so those questions will come out again.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Next week, when we meet next week with them again, we'll bring it up to them again.

[Caraviello]: OK.

[Caraviello]: Yeah, we only got halfway through right halfway through.

[Caraviello]: Dear Mr. President and city councils,

[Caraviello]: Whereas the strength of our nation is derived from its history of diversity that has enriched our community with a variety of cultures, faith, traditions, and viewpoints.

[Caraviello]: And whereas the city of Medford is a community that welcomes and values the very racial and ethnic makeup of our residents.

[Caraviello]: And whereas the city of Medford stands in support of all immigrant groups and newcomers as they pursue the American dream.

[Caraviello]: And whereas the city of Medford

[Caraviello]: will work to model our city as a safe and welcoming place that equally encourages all to speak, seek personal advancement, and to reside in peaceful consentment and method.

[Caraviello]: And the safe method rejects all words and acts of hate, indifference, and intolerance that undermine our neighbors, communities of faith, and our schools, and thwart the promise of equal justice.

[Caraviello]: Whereas our nation was founded

[Caraviello]: on the fundamental principles that all persons are entitled to equal protection of law, equal opportunity, and the enjoyment of civil and human rights.

[Caraviello]: 23rd regular meeting of the Medford City Council, June 13th, 2017.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Present.

[Caraviello]: Please rise and salute the flag.

[Caraviello]: and to the flag of the United States of America, and to the republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, if you could please mark Councilor Knight as being present.

[Caraviello]: Motions, orders, or resolutions.

[Caraviello]: 17-519, offered by Councilor Knight, be it resolved that the City Administration report to the Council the following, a listing of all collective bargaining agreements entered into by the School Department and the City of Bedford with employee organizations, including the effective dates of each agreement and the current status of any ongoing successor agreement negotiations.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Knight,

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: All those in favor?

[Caraviello]: in remediation of such leaks.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Lungo-Koehn.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Lengel-Kern.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: On the motion by Councilor Lungo-Koehn, seconded by Councilor Scapelli.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, roll call has been requested.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Six in the affirmative.

[Caraviello]: One in the negative motion passes.

[Caraviello]: Motion by Councilor Falco is to take a paper out of order.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Falco.

[Caraviello]: All those in favor?

[Caraviello]: 17-523, offered by Councilor Lungo-Koehn.

[Caraviello]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council send a written communication to Massport requesting that they- Are we still under suspension?

[Caraviello]: Uh, we just went out of order.

[Caraviello]: That's all we wrote.

[Caraviello]: We just went out of order.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Knight.

[Caraviello]: With time is of the essence on this, maybe we say we'll get this done quicker.

[Caraviello]: Whatever the body wants to do.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: On the motion by Councilor Marks, seconded by Councilor Naix, roll call vote has been requested.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Six in the affirmative, one absent.

[Caraviello]: Motion to revert back to regular order.

[Caraviello]: 17-523 offered by Councilor Lungo-Koehn.

[Caraviello]: requesting that they provide the city of Medford with a noise monitor to be placed above the Andrews School as well as the Medford Heights.
